[11:101] That is of the tidings of the <i>ruined</i> cities, We relate it to thee. Of them <i>some</i> are standing and <i>some</i> have been mown down <i>like the harvest</i>.
[11:102] And We did not wrong them, but they wronged themselves; and their gods on whom they called beside Allah were of no avail to them at all when the command of thy Lord came; and they added to them naught but perdition.
[11:103] Such is the grasp of thy Lord when He seizes the cities while they are doing wrong. Surely, His grasp is grievous <i>and</i> severe.
[11:104] In that surely is a Sign for him who fears the punishment of the Hereafter. That is a day for which <i>all</i> mankind shall be gathered together and that is a day <i>the proceedings of</i> which shall be witnessed <i>by all</i>.
[11:105] And We delay it not save for a computed term.
[11:106] The day it comes, no soul shall speak except by His permission; then <i>some</i> of them will prove unfortunate and <i>others</i> fortunate.
[11:107] As for those who will prove unfortunate, they shall be in the Fire, wherein there shall be for them sighing and sobbing,
[11:108] Abiding therein so long as the heavens and the earth endure, excepting what thy Lord may will. Surely, thy Lord does bring about what He pleases.
[11:109] But as for those who will prove fortunate, they shall be in Heaven; abiding therein so long as the heavens and the earth endure, excepting what thy Lord may will — a gift that shall not be cut off.
[11:110] So be not in doubt concerning that which these <i>people</i> worship. They only worship as their fathers worshipped before, and We shall surely pay them in full their portion undiminished.
[11:111] And We certainly gave Moses the Book, but differences were created therein; and had it not been for a word already gone forth from thy Lord, surely, the matter would have been decided between them <i>long before</i>; and <i>now</i> these <i>people</i> are in a disquieting doubt concerning it.
[11:112] And surely, <i>the works of</i> all <i>these have</i> not yet <i>been requited but</i> thy Lord will certainly repay them in full, according to their works. He is surely well aware of all that they do.
[11:113] So stand thou upright, as thou hast been commanded, and <i>also</i> those who have turned <i>to God</i> with thee; and exceed ye not the bounds, <i>O believers</i>; <i>for</i> surely, He sees what you do.
[11:114] And incline not toward those who do wrong, lest the Fire touch you. And you shall have no friends beside Allah, nor shall you be helped.
[11:115] And observe Prayer at the two ends of the day, and in the hours of the night <i>that are nearer the day</i>. Surely, good works drive away evil works. This is a reminder for those who would remember. Footnote: And observe Prayer at the two ends of the day, and <b>parts</b> of the night <i><b>close to</b> the day.</i> <b>Surely virtues drive away evils.</b>
[11:116] And be thou steadfast; for surely, Allah suffers not the reward of the righteous to perish.
[11:117] Why, then, were there not among the generations before you persons possessed of understanding who would have forbidden corruption in the earth — except a few of those whom We saved from among them? But the wrongdoers followed that by which they were afforded ease and comfort, and they became guilty.
[11:118] And thy Lord would not destroy the cities unjustly while the people thereof were righteous.
[11:119] And if thy Lord had <i>enforced</i> His will, He would have surely made mankind one people; but they would not cease to differ,
[11:120] Save those on whom thy Lord has had mercy, and for this has He created them. But the word of thy Lord shall be fulfilled: ‘Verily, I will fill Hell with <i>the disobedient</i> Jinn and men all together.’
[11:121] And all of the tidings of the Messengers, whereby We make thy heart firm, We relate unto thee. And herein has come to thee the truth and an exhortation and a reminder for believers.

[11:123] ‘And wait ye, we <i>too</i> are waiting.’

[12:5] <i>Remember the time</i> when Joseph said to his father, ‘O my father, I saw <i>in a dream</i> eleven stars and the sun and the moon, I saw them making obeisance to me.’
[12:6] He said, ‘O my darling son, relate not thy dream to thy brothers, lest they contrive a plot against thee; for Satan is to man an open enemy.
[12:7] ‘And thus <i>shall it be as thou hast seen</i>, thy Lord will choose thee and teach thee the interpretation of things and perfect His favour upon thee and upon the family of Jacob as He perfected it upon two of thy forefathers — Abraham and Isaac. Verily, thy Lord is All-Knowing, Wise.’ Footnote: ‘And thus <i>shall it be as <b>you have</b> seen,</i> <b>your</b> Lord will choose <b>you</b> and teach <b>you</b> the interpretation of <b>narrated matters</b> and perfect His favor upon <b>you</b> and upon the family of Jacob as He perfected it upon two of <b>your</b> forefathers – Abraham and Isaac. Verily, <b>your</b> Lord is All-Knowing, Wise.
[12:8] Surely, in Joseph and his brethren there are Signs for the inquirers.
[12:9] When they said, ‘Verily, Joseph and his brother are dearer to our father than we are, although we are a strong party. Surely, our father is in manifest error.
[12:10] ‘Kill Joseph or cast him out to some <i>distant</i> land, so that your father’s favour may become exclusively yours and you can thereafter become a righteous people.’
[12:11] One of them said, ‘Kill not Joseph, but if you must do something, cast him into the bottom of a deep well; some of the travellers will pick him up.’
[12:12] They said, ‘O our father, why dost thou not trust us with respect to Joseph, when we are certainly his sincere well-wishers?
[12:13] ‘Send him with us tomorrow that he may enjoy himself and play, and we shall surely keep guard over him.’
[12:14] He said, ‘It grieves me that you should take him away, and I fear lest the wolf should devour him while you are heedless of him.’
[12:15] They said, ‘Surely, if the wolf devour him while we are a strong party, then we shall indeed be <i>great</i> losers.’
[12:16] So, when they took him away, and agreed to put him into the bottom of a deep well, <i>they had their malicious design carried out</i>; and We sent a revelation to him, <i>saying</i>, ‘Thou shalt surely <i>one day</i> tell them of this affair of theirs and they shall not know.’ Footnote: So, when they took him away, and agreed to put him into the bottom of a deep well, We sent a revelation to him, saying ‘<b>You shall</b> surely <i>one day</i> tell them of this affair of theirs while <b>they will be unaware <i>of your identity</i></b>.’
[12:17] And they came to their father in the evening, weeping.
[12:18] They said, ‘O our father, we sent forth racing with one another, and left Joseph with our things, and the wolf devoured him, but thou wilt not believe us even if we speak the truth.’
[12:19] And they came with false blood on his shirt. He said, ‘Nay, but your souls have made a <i>great</i> thing appear light in your eyes. So <i>now</i> comely patience <i>is good for me</i>. And it is Allah <i>alone</i> Whose help is to be sought against what you assert.’ Footnote: He said, ‘Nay, but your <b>minds</b> have made <b>this <i>sinful</i> deed appear attractive to you.</b> So <i>now</i> <b>dignified</b> patience <i>is good for me.</i>
[12:20] And there came a caravan of travellers and they sent their waterdrawer. And he let down his bucket <i>into the well</i>. ‘Oh, good news!’ said he, ‘Here is a youth!’ And they concealed him as a piece of merchandise, and Allah knew full well what they did.
[12:21] And they sold him for a paltry price, a few dirhems, and they were not desirous of it. Footnote: And they sold him for a paltry price, a few dirhems, <b>and they were not keen to profit from him.</b>
[12:22] And the man from Egypt who bought him said to his wife, ‘Make his stay honourable. [12:23] And when he attained his <i>age of</i> full strength, We granted him judgment and knowledge. And thus do We reward the doers of good. Footnote: And when he <b>reached the age of maturity</b>, We granted him judgement and knowledge.
[12:24] And she, in whose house he was, sought to seduce him against his will. And she bolted the doors, and said, ‘Now come.’ He said, ‘I seek refuge with Allah. He is my Lord. He has made my stay <i>with you</i> honourable. Verily, the wrongdoers never prosper.’
[12:25] And she made up her mind with regard to him, and he made up his mind with regard to her. If he had not seen a manifest Sign of his Lord, <i>he could not have shown such determination</i>. Thus was it, that We might turn away from him evil and indecency. Surely, he was <i>one</i> of Our chosen servants. Footnote: <b>And she fell for him and he <i>too</i> would have fallen for her, had he not seen the sign of his Lord.</b>
[12:26] And they both raced to the door, and she tore his shirt from behind, and they found her lord at the door. She said, ‘What shall be the punishment of one who intended evil to thy wife, save imprisonment or a grievous chastisement?’
[12:27] He said, ‘She it was who sought to seduce me against my will.’ And a witness of her household bore witness <i>saying</i>, ‘If his shirt is torn from the front, then she has spoken the truth and he is of the liars.
[12:28] ‘But if his shirt is torn from behind, then she has lied and he is of the truthful.’
[12:29] So when he saw his shirt torn from behind, he said, ‘Surely, this is a device of you women. Your device is indeed mighty.
[12:30] ‘O Joseph, turn away from this and thou, <i>O woman</i>, ask forgiveness for thy sin. Certainly, thou art of the guilty.’
[12:31] And women in the city said, ‘The wife of the ‘Aziz seeks to seduce her slave-boy against his will. He has infatuated her with love. Indeed, we see her in manifest error.’
[12:32] And when she heard of their <i>crafty</i> design, she sent for them and prepared for them a repast, and gave every one of them a knife and <i>then</i> said <i>to Joseph</i>, ‘Come forth to them.’ And when they saw him they thought much of him and cut their hands, and said, ‘Allah be glorified! This is not a human being; this is but a noble angel.’ Footnote: <b>Note:</b> The words <i>qatta’na aidiyahunna</i> (<b></b>) ‘cut their hands’ can be understood to apply literally or metaphorically as Hadrat Imam Raghib has mentioned both usages with reference to the use of this word in the Holy Qur’an. (p) Here the literal meaning of (<b></b>) would be to sever one’s hand with some sharp instrument. This obviously is not meant by the Holy Qur’an and is inconceivable in this context. As an alternative, some scholars have attempted to attribute a minimized action of cutting, indicating just a few minor cuts, but the Arabic usage does not approve of it because the force and the intensity of the root meaning in the measure of (<b></b>) does not permit this mild connotation. The only choice therefore is between the literal and metaphorical meaning and we believe that this expression in the given context can only be rightly understood metaphorically, meaning that they accepted defeat by considering him inaccessible and beyond the reach of their hands.
[12:33] She said, ‘And this is he about whom you blamed me. I did seek to seduce him against his will, but he preserved himself <i>from sin</i>. And now if he do not what I bid him, he shall certainly be imprisoned and become <i>one</i> of the humbled.’
[12:34] He said, ‘O my Lord, I would prefer prison to that to which they invite me; and unless Thou turn away their guile from me I shall incline towards them and be of the ignorant.’
[12:35] So his Lord heard his prayer, and turned away their guile from him. Verily, He is the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing.
[12:36] Then it occurred to them (the men) after they had seen the signs <i>of his innocence</i> that, <i>to preserve their good name</i>, they should imprison him for a time.
[12:37] And with him there entered the prison two young men. Inform us of the interpretation thereof; for we see thee to be of the righteous.’

[12:39] ‘And I have followed the religion of my fathers, Abraham and Isaac and Jacob. We cannot indeed associate anything as partner with Allah. This is of Allah’s grace upon us and upon mankind, but most men are ungrateful.
[12:40] ‘O my two companions of the prison, are diverse lords better or Allah, the One, the Most Supreme?
[12:41] ‘You worship nothing beside Allah, but <i>mere</i> names that you have named, you and your fathers; Allah has sent down no authority for that. The decision rests with Allah alone. He has commanded that you shall not worship anything save Him. That is the right religion, but most men know <i>it</i> not. Footnote: <b>Note:</b> The word <i>qayyim</i> (<b></b>) according to the usage of the Holy Qur’an has a connotation of being strong, powerful, right and possessing a staying power. It also signifies the ability to straighten and correct. Hence the fundamental, unchangeable constituents of faith common to all religions are referred to in the Holy Qur’an as <i>dinul-qayyimah</i> (<b></b>). (p) See 98:6 (Al-Bayyinah)

[12:70] And when they visited Joseph, he lodged his brother with himself. <i>And</i> he said, ‘I am thy brother; so <i>now</i> grieve not at what they have been doing.’
[12:71] And when he had provided them with their provision, he put the drinking-cup in his brother’s saddlebag. Then a crier cried, ‘O ye <i>men of the</i> caravan, you have been guilty of theft.’
[12:72] They said, turning towards them, ‘What is it that you miss?’
[12:73] They replied, ‘We miss the King’s measuring-cup, and whoso brings it shall have a camel-load, and I am surety for it.’
[12:74] They answered, ‘By Allah, you know well that we came not to act corruptly in the land, and we are not thieves.’
[12:75] They said, ‘What then shall be the punishment for it, if you <i>are found to</i> have told a lie?’
[12:76] They replied, ‘The punishment for it — he in whose saddlebag it is found shall himself be the penalty for it. Thus do we punish the wrongdoers.’
[12:77] Then he began <i>the search</i> with their sacks before the sack of his brother; then he took it out from his brother’s sack. Thus did We plan for Joseph. He could not have taken his brother under the King’s law unless Allah had <i>so</i> willed. We raise in degrees <i>of rank</i> whomsoever We please; and over every possessor of knowledge is One, Most-Knowing.
[12:78] They said, ‘If he has stolen, a brother of his had <i>also</i> committed theft before.’ But Joseph kept it secret in his heart and did not disclose it to them. He <i>simply</i> said, ‘You seem to be in the worst condition; and Allah knows best what you allege.’
[12:79] They said, ‘O exalted one, he has a very aged father, so take one of us in his stead; for we see thee to be of those who do good.’
[12:80] He replied, ‘Allah forbid that we should take <i>any</i> save him with whom we found our property; for then we should certainly be unjust.’

[12:89] And, when they came before him (Joseph), they said, ‘O exalted one, poverty has smitten us and our family, and we have brought a paltry sum of money, so give us the full measure, and be charitable to us. Surely, Allah rewards the charitable.’
[12:90] He said, ‘Do you know what you did to Joseph and his brother, when you were ignorant?’

[12:97] And when the bearer of glad tidings came, he laid it before him and he became enlightened. <i>Then</i> he said, ‘Did I not say to you: I know from Allah what you know not?’
[12:98] They said, ‘O our father, ask forgiveness of our sins for us; we have indeed been sinners.’
[12:99] He said, ‘I will certainly ask forgiveness for you of my Lord. Surely, He is the Most Forgiving, the Merciful.’
[12:100] And when they came to Joseph, he put up his parents with himself, and said, ‘Enter Egypt in peace, if it please Allah.’
[12:101] And he raised his parents upon the throne, and they <i>all</i> fell down prostrate <i>before God</i> for him. And he said, ‘O my father, this is the fulfilment of my dream of old. My Lord has made it true. And He bestowed a favour upon me when He took me out of the prison and brought you from the desert after Satan had stirred up discord between me and my brethren. Surely, my Lord is Benignant to whomsoever He pleases; for He is the All-Knowing, the Wise.
[12:102] ‘O my Lord, Thou hast bestowed power upon me and taught me the interpretation of dreams. O Maker of the heavens and the earth, Thou art my Protector in this world and the Hereafter. Let death come to me in a state of submission <i>to Thy will</i> and join me to the righteous.’ Footnote: ‘O my Lord <b>you have blessed me with a share of sovereignty</b> and taught me the interpretation of <b>things</b>.
[12:103] That is of the tidings of the unseen, <i>which</i> We reveal to thee. And thou wast not with them when they agreed upon their plan while they were plotting.
[12:104] And most men will not believe even though thou eagerly desire <i>it</i>.
[12:105] And thou dost not ask of them any reward for it. <i>On the contrary</i>, it is but <i>a source of</i> honour for all mankind. Footnote: And <b>you do</b> not ask of them any reward for it. <b>It is only an admonishment</b> for all mankind.
[12:106] And how many a Sign is there in the heavens and the earth, which they pass by, turning away from it.
[12:107] And most of them believe not in Allah without <i>also</i> attributing partners <i>to Him</i>.
[12:108] Do they, then, feel secure from the coming on them of an overwhelming punishment from Allah or the sudden coming of the Hour upon them while they are unaware?
[12:109] Say, ‘This is my way: I call unto Allah on sure knowledge, I and those who follow me. And Holy is Allah; and I am not of those who associate gods <i>with God</i>.’ Footnote: Say, ‘This is my way: I call unto Allah. <b>I occupy a position of manifest knowledge, so do also those</b> who follow me.
[12:110] And We sent not before thee <i>as Messengers</i> any but men, whom We inspired, from among the people of the towns. Have they not then travelled in the earth and seen what was the end of those before them? And surely, the abode of the Hereafter is better for those who fear God. Will you not then understand?
[12:111] Till, when the Messengers despaired <i>of the disbelievers</i> and they (the disbelievers) thought that they had been told a lie, Our help came to them, then was saved he whom We pleased. And Our chastisement cannot be averted from the sinful people. Footnote: <b>Until the time, when the Messengers despaired and perceived themselves to have been <i>taken</i> as liars, suddenly there came Our help to them and</b> then saved he whom We pleased.
[12:112] Assuredly, in their narrative is a lesson for men of understanding. It is not a thing that has been forged, but a fulfilment of that which is before it and a detailed exposition of all things, and a guidance and a mercy to a people who believe.
[13:1] In the name of Allah, the Gracious, the Merciful.
[13:2] Alif Lam Mim Ra. These are verses of the Book. And that which has been revealed to thee from thy Lord is the truth, but most men believe not. Footnote: I am Allah, the All-Knowing, the All-Seeing.
[13:3] Allah is He Who raised up the heavens without any pillars that you can see. Then He settled Himself on the Throne. And He pressed the sun and the moon into service: each pursues its course until an appointed term. He regulates it all. He clearly explains the Signs, that you may have a firm belief in the meeting with your Lord.
[13:4] And He it is Who spread out the earth and made therein mountains and rivers. And fruits of every kind He made therein in two sexes. He causes the night to cover the day. Therein, verily, are Signs for a people who reflect. Footnote: And He it is Who spread out the earth and made therein mountains and rivers. <b>And of the fruits He has made them in pairs, male and female.</b>
[13:5] And in the earth are <i>diverse</i> tracts, adjoining one another, and gardens of vines, and corn-fields, and datepalms, growing together from one root and <i>others</i> not so growing; they are watered with the same water, yet We make some of them excel others in fruit. Therein are Signs for a people who understand. Footnote: And in the earth are <i>diverse</i> tracts, adjoining one another, and gardens of vines, and <b>fields of grain</b>, and date-palms, growing together from one root and <i>others</i> not so growing;
[13:6] And if thou dost wonder, then wondrous indeed is their saying: ‘What! when we have become dust, shall we then be in <i>a state of</i> new creation?’ These it is who disbelieve in their Lord; and these it is who shall have shackles round their necks, and they shall be the inmates of the Fire, wherein they shall abide.
[13:7] And they want thee to hasten on the punishment in preference to good, whereas exemplary punishments have <i>already</i> occurred before them. And verily, thy Lord is full of forgiveness for mankind despite their wrongdoing, and verily, thy Lord is <i>also</i> strict in condign punishment. Footnote: <b>And they are eager to demand from you that you may have evil brought upon them rather than good,</b> whereas exemplary punishments have <i>already</i> occurred before them.
[13:8] And those who disbelieve say, ‘Wherefore has not a Sign been sent down to him from his Lord?’ Thou art, surely, a Warner. And there is a Guide for every people.
[13:9] Allah knows what every female bears, and what wombs diminish and what they cause to grow. And with Him everything has a <i>proper</i> measure.
[13:10] <i>He is the</i> Knower of the unseen and the seen, the Incomparably Great, the Most High.
[13:11] He among you who conceals <i>his</i> word, and he who utters it openly are equal <i>in His sight</i>; and <i>also</i> he who hides by night, and he who goes forth <i>openly</i> by day.
[13:12] For him (the Messenger) is a succession <i>of angels</i> before him and behind him; they guard him by the command of Allah. Surely, Allah changes not the condition of a people until they change that which is in their hearts. And when Allah wishes to punish a people, there is no repelling it, nor have they any helper beside Him.
[13:13] He it is Who shows you the lightning <i>to inspire</i> fear and hope, and He raises the heavy clouds.
[13:14] And the thunder glorifies Him with His praise and <i>likewise do</i> the angels for awe of Him; and He sends the thunderbolts, and smites therewith whom He wills, yet they dispute concerning Allah, while He is severe in punishing.
[13:15] Unto Him is the true prayer. And those on whom they call beside Him answer them not at all, except as he <i>is answered</i> who stretches forth his two hands toward water that it may reach his mouth, but it reaches it not. And the prayer of the disbelievers is but a thing wasted. Footnote: <b>To Him alone is addressed true prayer.</b>
[13:16] And to Allah submits whosoever is in the heavens and the earth willingly or unwillingly and <i>likewise do</i> their shadows, in the mornings and the evenings.
[13:17] Say, ‘Who is the Lord of the heavens and the earth?’ Say, ‘Allah.’ Say, ‘Have you then taken beside Him helpers who have no power for good or harm <i>even</i> for themselves?’ Say, ‘Can the blind and the seeing be equal? Or, can darkness be equal to light? Or, do they assign to Allah partners who have created the like of His creation so that the <i>two</i> creations appear similar to them?’ Say, ‘Allah <i>alone</i> is the Creator of all things, and He is the One, the Most Supreme.’
[13:18] He sends down water from the sky, so that valleys flow according to their measure, and the flood bears <i>on its surface</i> swelling foam. And from that which they heat in the fire, seeking <i>to make</i> ornaments or utensils, <i>comes out</i> a foam similar to it. Thus does Allah illustrate truth and falsehood. Now, as to the foam, it goes away as rubbish, but as to that which benefits men, it stays on the earth. Thus does Allah set forth parables.
[13:19] For those who respond to their Lord is <i>eternal</i> good; and <i>as for</i> those who respond not to Him, if they had all that is in the earth and the like of it added thereto, they would <i>readily</i> ransom themselves therewith. It is these that shall have an evil reckoning, and their abode is Hell. What a wretched place of rest!
[13:20] Is he, then, who knows that what has been revealed to thee from thy Lord is the truth, like one who is blind? <i>But</i> only those gifted with understanding will reflect:
[13:21] Those who fulfil Allah’s pact, and break not the covenant;
[13:22] And those who join what Allah has commanded to be joined, and fear their Lord, and dread the evil reckoning;
[13:23] And those who persevere in seeking the favour of their Lord, and observe Prayer, and spend out of that with which We have provided them, secretly and openly, and repel evil with good. It is these who shall have the <i>best</i> reward of the <i>final</i> Abode — 
[13:24] Gardens of Eternity. They shall enter them and <i>also</i> those who are righteous from among their fathers, and their wives and their children. And angels shall enter unto them from every gate, <i>saying</i>:
[13:25] ‘Peace be unto you, because you were steadfast; behold how excellent is the reward of the <i>final</i> Abode!’
[13:26] And those who break the covenant of Allah, after having established it and cut asunder what Allah has commanded to be joined, and act corruptly in the earth — on them is the curse and they shall have a grievous abode.
[13:27] Allah enlarges <i>His</i> provision for whomsoever He pleases and straitens <i>it for whomsoever He pleases</i>. And they rejoice in the present life, while the present life is but a <i>temporary</i> enjoyment as compared with that which is to come.
[13:28] And those who disbelieve say, ‘Why is not a Sign sent down to him from his Lord?’ Say, ‘Allah lets go astray those whom He wills and guides to Himself those who turn <i>to Him</i>:
[13:29] ‘Those who believe, and whose hearts find comfort in the remembrance of Allah. Aye! it is in the remembrance of Allah that hearts can find comfort;
[13:30] ‘Those who believe and do good works — happiness shall be theirs, and an excellent place of return.’
[13:31] Thus have We sent thee to a people, before whom other peoples have passed away, that thou mayest recite to them what We have revealed to thee, yet they disbelieve in the Gracious <i>God</i>. Say, ‘He is my Lord; there is no God but He. In Him do I put my trust and towards Him is my return.’
[13:32] And if there were a Qur’an by which mountains could be moved or by which the earth could be cut asunder or by which the dead could be spoken to, <i>they would not believe in it</i>. Nay, the matter rests entirely with Allah. Have not the believers <i>yet</i> come to know that, if Allah had <i>enforced</i> His will, He could have surely guided all mankind? And as for those who disbelieve, disaster shall not cease to befall them for what they have wrought or to alight near their home, until the promise of Allah comes to pass. Surely, Allah fails not in <i>His</i> promise.
[13:33] And surely, Messengers have been mocked at before thee; but I granted respite to those who disbelieved. Then I seized them, and how was then My punishment!
[13:34] Will then He, Who stands over every soul <i>to note</i> what it earns, <i>let them go unpunished</i>? Yet, they ascribe partners to Allah. Say, ‘Name them.’ Would you inform Him of what He does not know in the earth? Or, is it <i>a mere</i> empty saying? Nay, but the design of the disbelievers has been made <i>to appear</i> beautiful in their eyes, and they have been kept back from the <i>right</i> way. And he whom Allah lets go astray shall have no guide.
[13:35] For them is a punishment in the present life; and, surely, the punishment of the Hereafter is harder, and they will have no defender against Allah.
[13:36] The similitude of the Heaven promised to the God-fearing is, that through it flow streams: its fruit is everlasting, and <i>so is</i> its shade. That is the reward of those who are righteous; and the reward of the disbelievers is Fire.
[13:37] And those to whom We have given the Book rejoice in what has been revealed to thee. And of the <i>different</i> parties there are <i>some</i> who deny a part thereof. Say, ‘I am only commanded to worship Allah and not to set up equals to Him. Unto Him do I call, and unto Him is my return.’
[13:38] And thus have We revealed it as a clear judgment. And if thou follow their evil desires after the knowledge that has come to thee, thou shalt have no friend nor defender against Allah.
[13:39] And, indeed, We sent Messengers before thee, and We gave them wives and children. And it is not possible for a Messenger to bring a Sign save by the command of Allah. For every term there is a <i>divine</i> decree.
[13:40] Allah effaces what He wills and established <i>what He wills</i>, and with Him is the source of <i>all</i> commandments. Footnote: Allah effaces what He wills, and establishes <i>what</i> he <i>wills</i>, and with Him is the source of <i>all</i> <b>decrees</b>.
[13:41] And whether We make thee see <i>the fulfilment of</i> some of the things with which We threaten them or <i>whether</i> We make thee die, <i>it makes little difference</i>, for on thee lies only the delivery of the Message, and on Us the reckoning.
[13:42] Do they not see that We are visiting the land, reducing it from its outlying borders? And Allah judges; there is none to reverse His judgment. And He is swift at reckoning.
[13:43] And those who were before them did <i>also</i> devise plans, but all <i>effective</i> devising of plans belongs to Allah. He knows what every soul earns; and the disbelievers shall soon know whose will be the final reward of <i>this</i> abode.

[14:7] And <i>call to mind</i> when Moses said to his people, ‘Remember Allah’s favour upon you when He delivered you from Pharaoh’s people who afflicted you with grievous torment, slaying your sons and sparing your women; and in that there was a great trial for you from your Lord.’
[14:8] And <i>remember also the time</i> when your Lord declared, ‘If you are grateful, I will, surely, bestow more <i>favours</i> on you; but if you are ungrateful, <i>then know that</i> My punishment is severe indeed.’
[14:9] And Moses said, ‘If you disbelieve, you and those who are in the earth all together, <i>you can do no harm to God</i>; verily, Allah is Self- Sufficient, Praiseworthy.’
[14:10] Have not the tidings come to you of those before you, the people of Noah, and <i>the tribes of</i> ‘Ad and Thamud, and those after them? None knows them <i>now</i> save Allah. Their Messengers came to them with clear Signs, but they turned their hands to their mouths, and said, ‘We disbelieve in that with which you have been sent and surely, we are in disquieting doubt concerning that to which you call us.’
[14:11] Their Messengers said, ‘Are you in doubt concerning Allah, Maker of the heavens and the earth? He calls you that He may forgive you your sins, and grant you respite till an appointed term.’ They said, ‘You are but men like ourselves; you desire to turn us away from that which our fathers used to worship. Bring us, then, a clear proof.’ Footnote: <b>Note:</b> The Quranic expression <i>faraddu aidiyahum fi afwahihim</i> (<b></b>) (they turned their hands to their mouths) paints a picture of somebody putting his hand to his mouth indicating blockade. Before explaining this special expression one has also to determine as to who is referred to in this verse. Evidently this act is attributed to non-believers; so it has two possibilities of interpretation. It can be translated as; <b>they, the non-believers, thrust their hands into their own mouths.</b> This means that they refused to have any dialogue with the Messengers and their followers. This stage is reached when a person is ultimately nonplussed and is left with no arguments. So he acquires this posture of boycott, indicating that he has nothing more to say. (p) In the second reading the reference may be to the mouths of the Messengers. It also indicates the same break in dialogue but in a different way. Hence the message would be that the non-believers finally stop Messengers from further preaching telling them to shut their mouths. This alternative is further supported by the remaining part of the verse where the non-believers continue to develop the theme by saying further: ‘We have rejected the message with which you were sent and verily we are in manifold doubt regarding that to which you call us.’
[14:12] Their Messengers said to them, ‘We are indeed only men like yourselves, but Allah bestows <i>His</i> favour on whomsoever He wills from among His servants. And it is not for us to bring you a proof except by the command of Allah. And in Allah <i>alone</i> should the believers put their trust.
[14:13] ‘And why should we not put our trust in Allah when He has showed us our ways? And we will, surely, bear with patience <i>all</i> the harm you do us. So in Allah let those who trust put their trust.’
[14:14] And those who disbelieved said to their Messengers, ‘We will, surely, expel you from our land unless you return to our religion.’ Then their Lord sent unto them the revelation: ‘We will, surely, destroy the wrongdoers.
[14:15] ‘And We will, surely, make you dwell in the land after them. This is for him who fears to stand before My Tribunal and fears My warning.’ Footnote: ‘And We will, surely, make you dwell in the land after them. <b>That is for him who stands in awe of My station and takes head of My warning.’</b>
[14:16] And they prayed for victory, and <i>as a result thereof</i> every haughty enemy <i>of truth</i> came to naught.
[14:17] Before him is Hell; and he shall be made to drink boiling water.
[14:18] He shall sip it and shall not be able to swallow it easily. And death shall come to him from every quarter, <i>yet</i> he shall not die. And besides that there shall be <i>for him</i> a severe chastisement. Footnote: <b>He will drink it sip by sip, reluctantly, being unable to quaff it.</b>
[14:19] The case of those who disbelieve in their Lord is that their works are like ashes on which the wind blows violently on a stormy day. They shall have no power over what they earned. [15:90] And say, ‘I am, indeed, a plain Warner.’ Footnote: And say, <b>‘I am a plain Warner indeed.’</b>
[15:91] Because We <i>have decided to</i> send down <i>punishment</i> on those who have formed themselves into groups <i>against thee</i>; Footnote: <b>Like always We shall send down <i>punishment</i> upon those who become split into sects,</b>
[15:92] Who have pronounced the Qur’an to be <i>so many</i> lies; Footnote: <b><i>And</i> who would split the Qur’an into segments.</b> (p) <b>Note:</b> We prefer to translate the verses (88-92) in the future tense rather than the past because we consider them to possess a grave warning to Muslims. There is no wonder why the past tense is used to indicate future, because most of such prophecies as are inevitably bound to be fulfilled are expressed in the past tense in the Holy Qur’an. The past is unchangeable. Prophecies in the past tense emphasise certainty. Thus the translation should run as follows: (p) <b>“And We have, indeed given thee the seven oft repeated <i>verses</i> and the great Qur’an. Do not stretch your eyes <i>with greed</i> towards the transient pleasure We have bestowed upon various groups among them, and grieve not over them; and lower your wing <i>of mercy</i> for the believers. And say, I am a plain Warner indeed. Like always, We shall send down punishment upon those who become split into sects, and who would split the Qur’an into segments.”</b> (p) This translation becomes evidently more appropriate when we bring into view the context of these verses and discover that the preceding verses begin with a dramatic introduction of the Holy Qur’an as a great Book. So all those who, despite claiming subservience to the Qur’an, disregard its most central message of unity, and get split into sects to prove their own interpretation to be right end up by practically splitting the Qur’an into segments: each group sticking to some verses interpreting them to their own advantage as against others who stick to some other verses interpreting them to their own advantage. This split is described to be so sharp and final that there is left no possibility of compromise between different warring factions. This causes people of the same <i>ummah</i> to split into sects and in the same process to divide the Qur’an into segments.

[16:10] And upon Allah rests the <i>showing of the</i> right way, and there are ways which deviate <i>from the right course</i>. And if He had <i>enforced</i> His will, He would have guided you all.
[16:11] He it is Who sends down water for you from the clouds; out of it you have your drink, and there <i>grow</i> from it trees on which you pasture <i>your cattle.</i>
[16:12] Therewith He grows corn for you, and the olive and the datepalm, and the grapes, and all kinds of fruits. Surely, in that is a Sign for a people who reflect. Footnote: Therewith He grows <b>crops <i>of all kinds</i></b> for you, and the olive and the date-palm, and the grapes, and all <b>sorts</b> of fruits. Surely, in that is a Sign for a people who reflect.
[16:13] And He has pressed into service for you the night and the day, and the sun and the moon; and the stars <i>too</i> have been pressed into service by His command. Surely, in that are Signs for a people who make use of their reason.
[16:14] And <i>He has pressed into service</i> the things He has created for you in the earth, varying in colours. Surely, in that is a Sign for a people who take heed.
[16:15] And He it is Who has subjected <i>to you</i> the sea that you may eat therefrom fresh flesh, and may take forth therefrom ornaments which you wear. And thou seest the ships ploughing through it, <i>that you may thereby journey</i> and that you may seek of His bounty and that you may be grateful.
[16:16] And He has placed in the earth firm mountains lest it quake with you, and rivers and routes that you may take the right way. Footnote: And He has placed in the earth firm mountains <b>to sustain you</b>, and rivers and <b>paths so</b> that you <b>keep to the right path</b>. (p) <b>Note:</b> Many scholars have translated the phrase <i>an tumida bikum</i> (<b></b>) as ‘quake’ which if accepted would mean that God is counting His bounties upon mankind by reminding them that He has created mountains to cause great earthquakes spelling destructions far and wide. Unfortunately, it has been ignored that the word <i>tamida</i> (<b></b>) is derived from <i>mada</i> (<b></b>) which means to provide food. The word <i>ma’idah</i> (<b></b>) used in the Holy Qur’an is from the same infinitive. With this meaning in view the entire understanding of this verse will be transformed. It will remind mankind that God has created mountains which are essential for providing food to all living beings. The water is constantly lifted from lakes, seas and oceans by evaporation carried by higher altitude to get condensed into thicker particles. The existence of mountains is essential for turning the vapour into water again, thus producing widespread rains which are channeled back to earth to create immense food chains. This translation is the only one which fits into the context and is in perfect agreement with the remaining part of the verse. The correct meaning, therefore, would be: <b>‘He has entrenched mountains over the earth so that they may provide you with food, and rivers and tracks so that you may be guided.’</b> (p) The relation of water and food is obvious. In the history of civilization it was rivers which played the most important role in making the mountainous terrains possible and paths were carved along the courses of rivers.

[16:78] And to Allah belongs the unseen of the heavens and the earth; and the matter of the Hour is but as the twinkling of an eye, nay, it is nearer still. Surely, Allah has power over all things.
[16:79] And Allah brought you forth from the wombs of your mothers while you knew nothing, and gave you ears and eyes and hearts, that you might be grateful.
[16:80] Do they not see the birds held under subjection in the vault of heaven? None keeps them back save Allah. Verily, in that are Signs for a people who believe. Footnote: <b>Do they not observe the birds held <i>aloft</i> in midheaven? None keeps them held <i>aloft</i> but Allah.</b>
[16:81] And Allah has made your homes, a place of rest for you and has made for you, of the skins of cattle, abodes which you find light at the time when you travel and at the time when you halt; and of their wool, and their furs, and their hair, <i>He has supplied you with</i> household goods and articles of use for a time.
[16:82] And Allah has made for you, of that which He has created, <i>things affording</i> shade; and He has made for you, in the mountains, places of shelter; and He has made for you garments which protect you from heat, and coats of mail which protect you in your wars. Thus does He complete His favour on you, that you may submit <i>to Him</i>.
[16:83] But if they turn away, then thou art responsible only for the plain delivery of the Message.
[16:84] They recognize the favour of Allah, yet they deny it; and most of them are <i>confirmed</i> disbelievers. Footnote: They <b>know full well Allah’s grace <i>as they see it</i></b> yet they deny it; and most of them are <b>ingrate</b>.
[16:85] And <i>remember</i> the day when We shall raise up a witness from every people, then those who disbelieve shall not be permitted <i>to make amends</i>, nor shall they be allowed to solicit <i>God’s</i> favour. Footnote: And <i>remember</i> the day when We shall raise up a witness from every people, then those who disbelieve shall not be <b>permitted <i>to plead</i> nor shall their plea be accepted</b>.
[16:86] And when those who did wrong <i>actually</i> see the punishment, it will not be made light for them, nor will they be granted respite.
[16:87] And when those who associate partners <i>with God</i> will see their associate-gods, they will say, ‘Our Lord, these are our associate-gods whom we used to call upon instead of Thee.’ Thereupon, they will retort on them with the words, ‘Surely, you are liars.’
[16:88] And they will offer submission to Allah on that day, and all that they used to forge shall fail them.
[16:89] <i>As for</i> those who disbelieve and turn <i>men</i> away from the way of Allah, We will add punishment to <i>their</i> punishment because they acted corruptly.
[16:90] And <i>remember</i> the day when We will raise up in every people a witness against them from amongst themselves, and We will bring thee as a witness against these. And We have sent down to thee the Book to explain everything, and a guidance, and a mercy, and glad tidings to those who submit <i>to God.</i>
[16:91] Verily, Allah enjoins justice, and the doing of good to others; and giving like kindred; and forbids indecency, and manifest evil, and wrongful transgression. He admonished you that you may take heed. Footnote: Verily, Allah <b>requires you to abide by justice, and to treat with grace, and give like the giving of kin to kin;</b> and forbids indecency, <b>and manifest evil, and transgression.</b>
[16:92] And fulfil the covenant of Allah when you have made; and break not the oaths after making them firm, while you have made Allah your surety. Certainly, Allah knows what you do.
[16:93] And be not like unto her who, after having made it strong, breaks her yarn into pieces. You make your oaths a means of deceit between you, <i>for fear</i> lest one people become more powerful than another. Surely, Allah tries you therewith, and on the Day of Resurrection He will make clear to you that wherein you differed.
[16:94] And if Allah had <i>enforced</i> His will, He would surely have made you <i>all</i> one people; but He lets go astray him who wishes <i>it</i>, and guides him who wishes <i>it</i>; and you shall surely be questioned concerning that which you have been doing.
[16:95] And make not your oaths a means of deceit between you; or <i>your</i> foot will slip after it has been firmly established, and you will taste evil because you turned <i>people</i> away from the path of Allah, and you will have a severe punishment.
[16:96] And barter not the covenant of Allah for a paltry price. Surely, that which is with Allah is better for you if you only knew.
[16:97] That which you have shall pass away, but that which is with Allah is lasting. And We will certainly give those who are steadfast their reward according to the best of their works. Footnote: That which you have shall <b>come to naught and whatever is with Allah will last <i>forever</i></b>.
[16:98] Whoso acts righteously, whether male or female, and is a believer, We will surely grant him a pure life; and We will surely bestow on such their reward according to the best of their works.
[16:99] And when thou recitest the Qur’an, seek refuge with Allah from Satan the rejected.
[16:100] Surely, he has no power over those who believe and who put their trust in their Lord.
[16:101] His power is only over those who make friends with him and who set up equals to Him.
[16:102] And when We bring one Sign in place of another — and Allah knows best what He reveals — they say, ‘Thou art but a fabricator.’ Nay, but most of them know not.
[16:103] Say, ‘The Spirit of holiness has brought it down from thy Lord with truth, that He may strengthen those who believe, and as a guidance and glad tidings for Muslims.’
[16:104] And indeed We know that they say that it is only a man who teaches him. <i>But</i> the tongue of him to whom they <i>unjustly</i> incline <i>in making this insinuation</i> is foreign, while this is Arabic tongue, plain and clear.
[16:105] <i>As for</i> those who do not believe in the Signs of Allah, surely, Allah will not guide them, and they shall have a grievous punishment.
[16:106] It is only those who believe not in the Signs of Allah, that forge falsehood, and they it is who are the liars.
[16:107] Whoso disbelieves in Allah after he has believed — save him who is forced <i>thereto</i> while his heart finds peace in the faith — but such as open their breasts to disbelief, on them is Allah’s wrath; and they shall have a severe punishment. Footnote: <b>Whoever disbelieves in Allah after having believed except the one who is coerced <i>beyond the limit of his tolerance</i> while his heart remains firm in faith. But those whose hearts are content with rejection, upon them will fall the wrath of Allah and for them shall be a great chastisement.</b>
[16:108] That is because they have preferred the present life to the Hereafter, and because Allah guides not the disbelieving people.
[16:109] It is they on whose hearts and ears and eyes Allah has set a seal. And it is they who are the heedless.
[16:110] Undoubtedly, it is they who will be the losers in the Hereafter.
[16:111] Then, surely, thy Lord — to those who fled <i>their homes</i> after they had been persecuted and then struggled hard <i>in the cause of Allah</i> and remained steadfast — <i>aye</i>, surely, after that thy Lord is Most Forgiving, Merciful.
[16:112] On the day when every soul will come pleading for itself, and every soul will be fully recompensed for what it did, and they will not be wronged.
[16:113] And Allah sets forth <i>for you</i> the parable of a city which enjoyed security and peace; its provisions came to it in plenty from every quarter; but it denied the favours of Allah, so Allah made it taste hunger and fear <i>which clothed it like</i> a garment because of what they used to do. Footnote: And Allah sets forth the parable <b>of a township</b> which enjoyed security and peace; its provisions came to it in plenty from every quarter; but it denied the favours of Allah, so Allah made <b>its dwellers taste a life wrapped in hunger and fear as a consequence</b> of what they used to do.
[16:114] And indeed there has come to them a Messenger from among themselves, but they treated him as a liar, so punishment overtook them while they were wrongdoers.
[16:115] So eat of the lawful <i>and</i> good things which Allah has provided for you; and be grateful for the bounty of Allah, if it is Him you worship.
[16:116] He has made unlawful for you only that which dies of itself and blood and the flesh of swine and that on which the name of any other than Allah has been invoked. But he who is driven by necessity, being neither disobedient nor exceeding the limit, then surely, Allah is Most Forgiving, Merciful. Footnote: He has <b>only</b> made unlawful for you to partake <b>of the flesh <i>of such animals</i> as have died a natural death</b> and of blood and the flesh of swine and that on which the name of any other than Allah has been invoked. <b>But who is driven by extreme compulsion without relish or intent to transgress,</b> then surely, Allah is Most Forgiving, Merciful.
[16:117] And say not — because of the falsehood which your tongues utter — ‘This is lawful, and this is unlawful,’ so as to forge a lie against Allah. Surely, those who forge a lie against Allah do not prosper.
[16:118] <i>It is</i> a brief enjoyment, and <i>then</i> they shall have a grievous punishment. Footnote: <b><i>After a</i> small gain, for them there is a grievous punishment.</b>
[16:119] And to those <i>also</i> who are Jews, We forbade before <i>this</i> all that We have related to thee. And We wronged them not, but they used to wrong themselves.
[16:120] Then surely, thy Lord — to those who do evil in ignorance and repent thereafter and make amends — <i>aye</i>, surely, after that thy Lord is Most Forgiving, Merciful.
[16:121] Abraham was indeed a paragon of virtue, obedient to Allah, ever inclined <i>to Him</i>, and he was not of those who set up equals <i>to God</i>; Footnote: <b>Abraham was a nation unto himself, always obedient to Allah, <i>to Him</i> ever inclined; certainly not belonging to the idolaters.’</b> <b>Note:</b> Abraham was a nation unto himself means that he had the seed and the potential of a great nation promised unto him.
[16:122] Grateful for His favours; He chose him and guided him to a straight path. Footnote: <b>Ever</b> grateful for His favours; He chose him and guided him to a straight path.
[16:123] And We bestowed on him good in this world, and in the Hereafter he will surely be among the righteous.
[16:124] And <i>now</i> We have revealed to thee, <i>saying</i>, ‘Follow the way of Abraham <i>who was</i> ever inclined <i>to God</i> and was not of those who set up equals <i>to Him</i>.’
[16:125] The <i>punishment for profaning</i> the Sabbath was imposed only on those who had differed about it, and thy Lord will surely judge between them on the day of Resurrection about that in which they differed. Footnote: The <i>punishment for profaning</i> the Sabbath was imposed <b>upon those who differed regarding him, <i>Abraham and his religion</i>, and your</b> Lord will surely judge between them on the Day of Resurrection about that in which they differed. <b>Note:</b> The context is clear. Nothing but Abraham and his unshakeable devotion and dedication to the Oneness of God is being discussed. Hence the reference has to be to Abraham and the differences the Israelites had among themselves regarding his true faith and conduct. Many among them had fallen prey to different forms of idolatry and it is quite likely that to justify their practices they might have attributed them also to Abraham. The Sabbath in this context appears to be not only a day of rest but also a day of purification and penance.
[16:126] Call unto the way of thy Lord with wisdom and goodly exhortation, and argue with them in a way that is best. Surely, thy Lord knows best who has strayed from His way; and He knows those who are rightly guided.
[16:127] And if you <i>desire to</i> punish <i>the oppressors</i>, then punish <i>them</i> to the extent to which you have been wronged; but if you show patience, then, surely, that is best for those who are patient.
[16:128] And endure thou with patience; and verily, thy patience is <i>possible</i> only with <i>the help of</i> Allah. And grieve not for them, nor feel distressed because of their plots.
[16:129] Verily, Allah is with those who are righteous and those who do good.
[17:1] In the name of Allah, the Gracious, the Merciful.
[17:2] Glory be to Him Who carried His servant by night from the Sacred Mosque to the Distant Mosque, the environs of which We have blessed, that We might show him <i>some</i> of Our Signs. Surely, He alone is the Hearing, the Seeing. Footnote: Glory be to Him <b>Who took His servant along</b> by night from the Sacred Mosque to the Distant Mosque, the environs of which We have blessed, that We might show him <i>some</i> of Our Signs.
[17:3] And We gave Moses the Book, and We made it a guidance for the children of Israel, <i>saying</i>, ‘Take no guardian beside Me,
[17:4] ‘O ye the progeny of those whom We carried <i>in the Ark</i> with Noah.’ He was indeed a grateful servant.
[17:5] And We revealed to the children of Israel in the Book, <i>saying</i>, ‘You will surely do mischief in the land twice, and you will surely become excessively overbearing.’
[17:6] So when the time for the first of the two warnings came, We sent against you <i>some</i> servants of Ours possessed of great might in war, and they penetrated the <i>innermost parts of your</i> houses, and it was a warning that was bound to be carried out. Footnote: So when the time for the first of the two warnings came <b><i>to be fulfilled</i></b>, We sent against you <i>some</i> servants of Ours possessed of great might in war <b>who penetrated deep into <i>your</i> houses</b>, and it was a warning that was bound to be carried out.
[17:7] Then We gave you back the power against them, and aided you with wealth and children, and made you larger in numbers.
[17:8] <i>Now</i>, if you do well, you will do well for your own souls; and if you do evil, it will <i>only go</i> against them. So when the time for the latter warning came, <i>We raised a people against you</i> to cover your faces with grief, and to enter the Mosque as they entered it the first time, and to destroy all that they conquered with utter destruction. Footnote: <b>If you conduct yourselves well, you will do the advantage to your own souls; and if you misconduct, you will do it to your disadvantage. So when the promised hour of the latter days comes they should bring you to disgrace, and enter the Mosque the way they entered therein the first time and destroy utterly everything they conquered.</b>
[17:9] It may be that your Lord will <i>now</i> have mercy on you; but if you return <i>to your previous state,</i> We <i>too</i> will return, and We have made Hell a prison for the disbelievers.
[17:10] Surely, this Qur’an guides to what is most right; and gives to the believers who do good deeds the glad tidings that they shall have a great reward.
[17:11] And that for those who do not believe in what is to come later We have prepared a grievous punishment.
[17:12] And man asks for evil as he should ask for good; and man is hasty. Footnote: <b>And man begs for evil as though he were begging for good;</b> and man is hasty.
[17:13] And We have made the night and the day two Signs, and the Sign of night We have made dark, and the Sign of day We have made sightgiving, that you may seek bounty from your Lord, and that you may know the computation of years and <i>the science of</i> reckoning. And everything We have explained with a detailed explanation. Footnote: And We have made the night and the day two Signs, <b>and We erased the Sign of night <i>replacing it with day</i></b> and the Sign of the day We have made <b>alight</b>, that you may seek bounty from your Lord, and that you may know the computation of years and <i>the sciences of</i> reckoning.
[17:14] And every man’s works have We fastened to his neck, and on the Day of Resurrection We shall bring out for him a book which he will find wide open. Footnote: And every man’s <b>record of deeds have we fastened</b> to his neck, and on the Day of Resurrection We shall bring out for him a book which he will find wide open.
[17:15] ‘Read thy book. Sufficient is thy own soul this day as reckoner against thee.’
[17:16] He who follows the right way follows it only for <i>the good of</i> his <i>own</i> soul: and he who goes astray, goes astray only to his <i>own</i> loss. And no bearer of burden shall bear the burden of another. We never punish until We have sent a Messenger.
[17:17] And when We intend to destroy a township, We address Our commandment to its rebellious people, but they transgress therein; so the sentence <i>of punishment</i> becomes due against it, and We destroy it with utter destruction. Footnote: And when We intend to destroy a township, <b>We permit the affluent among them <i>to do as they please</i>. So they indulge in all manners of sin therein, till the decree is justified to befall it. Then We destroy it utterly.</b>
[17:18] How many generations have We destroyed after Noah! And thy Lord suffices as the Knower and Seer of the sins of His servants.
[17:19] Whoso desires the present life, We hasten for him therein what We will — for such <i>of them</i> as We please; then have We appointed Hell for him; he shall burn therein, condemned <i>and</i> rejected.
[17:20] And whoso desires the Hereafter and strives for it as it should be striven for, and he is a believer — these are the ones whose striving shall find favour <i>with God</i>.
[17:21] To all We render aid — both to these and those — a gift from thy Lord. And the gift of thy Lord is not restricted.
[17:22] Behold, how We have exalted some of them over others <i>in the present life</i>; and surely, the Hereafter shall be greater in degrees <i>of rank</i> and greater in excellence.
[17:23] Set not up with Allah another God lest thou sit down disgraced <i>and</i> forsaken.
[17:24] Thy Lord has commanded, “Worship none but Him, and <i>show</i> kindness to parents. If one of them or both of them attain old age with thee, never say unto them any word expressive of disgust nor reproach them, but address them with excellent speech. Footnote: If one of them or both of them attain old age with thee, never say unto them any word expressive of disgust nor reproach them, but address them with <b>kind words</b>.
[17:25] “And lower to them the wing of humility out of tenderness. And say, ‘My Lord, have mercy on them even as they nourished me in <i>my</i> childhood.’”
[17:26] Your Lord knows best what is in your minds; if you are righteous, then surely, He is Most Forgiving to those who turn <i>to Him</i> again and again.
[17:27] And give thou to the kinsman his due, and to the poor and the wayfarer, and squander not <i>thy wealth</i> extravagantly.
[17:28] Verily, the extravagant are brothers of satans, and Satan is ungrateful to his Lord.
[17:29] And if thou hast to turn away from them while seeking thy Lord’s mercy for which thou hopest, <i>even then</i> speak to them a gentle word.
[17:30] And keep not thy hand chained to thy neck, nor stretch it out an entire stretching, lest thou sit down blamed <i>or</i> exhausted. Footnote: And keep not <b>your</b> hand chained to <b>your</b> neck <b><i>in utter stinginess</i> nor extend it in extravagance to the full; or you will end up roundly condemned <i>and</i> rendered ineffectual.</b>
[17:31] Surely, thy Lord enlarges <i>His</i> provision for whom He pleases, and straitens <i>it for whom He pleases</i>. Verily, He knows <i>and</i> sees His servants full well.
[17:32] Kill not your children for fear of poverty. It is We Who provide for them and for you. Surely, the killing of them is a great sin.
[17:33] And come not near unto adultery; surely, it is a foul thing and an evil way.
[17:34] And kill not the soul which Allah has forbidden save for just cause. And whoso is killed wrongfully, We have surely given his heir authority <i>to demand retaliation</i>, but let him not exceed the <i>prescribed</i> bounds in slaying; for <i>therein</i> he is helped <i>by law</i>.
[17:35] And come not near the property of the orphan, except in the best way, until he attains his maturity, and fulfil the covenant; for the covenant shall be questioned about.
[17:36] And give full measure when you measure, and weigh with a right balance; that is best and most commendable in the end.
[17:37] And follow not that of which thou hast no knowledge. Verily, the ear and the eye and the heart — all these shall be called to account.
[17:38] And walk not in the earth haughtily, for thou canst not rend the earth, nor canst thou reach the mountains in height.
[17:39] The evil of all these is hateful in the sight of thy Lord.
[17:40] This is part of that wisdom which thy Lord has revealed to thee. And set not up with Allah any other God, lest thou be cast into Hell, condemned <i>and</i> rejected.
[17:41] Has, then, your Lord honoured you with sons, and taken for Himself females from among the angels? Surely, you say a grievous saying.
[17:42] We have explained <i>the truth</i> in this Qur’an in the various ways that they may be admonished, but it only increases them in aversion.
[17:43] Say, had there been other gods with Him, as they say, then they (idolaters) would have surely sought out a way to the Owner of the Throne.
[17:44] Holy is He, and exalted far above that which they say.
[17:45] The seven heavens and the earth and those that are therein extol His glory; and there is not a thing but glorifies Him with His praise; but you understand not their glorification. Verily, He is Forbearing, Most Forgiving.
[17:46] And when thou recitest the Qur’an, We put between thee and those who believe not in the Hereafter a hidden veil;
[17:47] And We put coverings over their hearts lest they should understand it, and in their ears a deafness. And when thou makest mention in the Qur’an of thy Lord alone, they turn their backs in aversion. Footnote: <b>And upon their hearts We have drawn covers so that they do not understand it and inflicted their ears with deafness.</b>
[17:48] We know best what they listen for, when they listen to thee, and when they confer in private, when the wrongdoers say, ‘You follow none but a man who is a victim of deception.’
[17:49] See, how they coin similitudes for thee, and have thus gone astray so that they cannot find a way.
[17:50] And they say, ‘When we shall have become bones and broken particles, shall we be really raised up as a new creation?’
[17:51] Say, ‘Be ye stones or iron,
[17:52] ‘Or created matter of <i>any kind</i> which appears hardest in your minds, <i>even then shall you be raised up</i>.’ Then will they ask, ‘Who shall restore us to life?’ Say, ‘He Who created you the first time.’ They will then shake their heads at thee and say, ‘When will it be?’ Say, ‘Maybe it is nigh,
[17:53] ‘<i>It will be</i> on the day when He will call you; then will you respond praising Him and you will think that you have tarried but a little while.’
[17:54] And say to My servants that they should speak that which is best. Surely, Satan stirs up discord among them. Surely, Satan is an open enemy to man.
[17:55] Your Lord knows you best. If He please, He will have mercy on you; or if He please, He will punish you. And We have not sent thee to be a keeper over them.
[17:56] And thy Lord knows best those that are in the heavens and the earth. And We exalted some of the Prophets over the others, and to David We gave a Book. Footnote: And thy Lord knows best those that are in the heavens and the earth. And We exalted some of the Prophets over the others and to David <b>We gave the Zabur.</b> <b>Note:</b> ‘<i>Zabur</i>’ means the Psalms.
[17:57] Say, ‘Call on those whom you think <i>to be gods</i> beside Him; then <i>you will know that</i> they have no power to remove affliction from you or to avert <i>it</i>.
[17:58] Those whom they call on <i>themselves</i> seek nearness to their Lord — <i>even</i> those of them who are nearest — and hope for His mercy, and fear His punishment. Surely, the punishment of thy Lord is a thing to be feared.
[17:59] There is not a township but We shall destroy it before the Day of Resurrection, or punish it with a severe punishment. That is written down in the Book.
[17:60] And nothing could hinder Us from sending Signs, except that the former people rejected them, <i>but this is no hindrance</i>. And We gave Thamud the she-camel as a clear Sign, but they unjustly rejected it. And We send not Signs but to warn.
[17:61] And <i>remember the time</i> when We said to thee: ‘Surely, thy Lord has encompassed the people.’ And We made not the vision which We showed thee but as a trial for men, as also the tree cursed in the Qur’an. And We warn them, but it only increases them in great transgression.
[17:62] And <i>remember the time</i> when We said to the angels, ‘Submit to Adam,’ and they <i>all</i> submitted, except Iblis. He said, ‘Shall I submit to one whom Thou hast created of clay?’
[17:63] <i>And</i> he said, ‘What thinkest Thou? <i>Can</i> this whom Thou hast honoured above me <i>be my superior</i>? If Thou wilt grant me respite till the Day of Resurrection, I will most surely bring his descendants under my sway except a few.’
[17:64] He said, ‘Begone! and whoso shall follow thee from among them, Hell shall surely be the recompense of you all — an ample recompense.
[17:65] ‘And entice whomsoever of them thou canst, with thy voice, and urge against them thy horsemen and thy footmen and be their partner in wealth, and children, and make promises to them.’ And Satan promises them naught but deceit.
[17:66] <i>As to</i> My servants, thou shalt certainly have no power over them, and sufficient is thy Lord as a Guardian.
[17:67] Your Lord is He Who drives for you the ships in the sea, that you may seek of His bounty. Surely, He is merciful toward you.
[17:68] And when harm touches you on the sea, <i>all</i> those whom you call upon, except Him, become lost <i>to you</i>. But when He brings you safe to land, you turn aside; and man is very ungrateful.
[17:69] Do you then feel secure that He will <i>not</i> cause you to sink in the side of the land or send against you a violent sandstorm <i>and</i> then you will find no guardian for yourselves?
[17:70] Or, do you feel secure that He will <i>not</i> send you back therein a second time, <i>and</i> then send against you as a storm-blast, and drown you because of your disbelief? You will then find therein no helper for yourselves against Us.
[17:71] Indeed, We have honoured the children of Adam, and carried them by land and sea, and given them of good things and exalted them far above many of those whom We have created.
[17:72] <i>Remember</i> the day when We shall summon every people with their Leader. Then whoso shall be given his book in his right hand — such will read their book, and they will not be wronged a whit.
[17:73] But whoso is blind in this world will be blind in the Hereafter, and even more astray from the way.
[17:74] And they had well-nigh caused thee <i>severest</i> affliction on account of what We have revealed to thee, that thou mightest invent against Us something other than that; and then they would have certainly taken thee for a <i>special</i> friend.
[17:75] And if We had not strengthened thee <i>with the Qur</i>’<i>an</i>, thou mightest have inclined to them a little.
[17:76] In that case We would have made thee taste similar <i>afflictions</i> of life and similar <i>afflictions</i> of death, <i>and</i> then thou wouldst not have found for thyself any helper against Us.
[17:77] And indeed they are near to unsettling thee from the land that they might expel thee therefrom; but in that case they <i>themselves</i> would not have stayed after thee save a little.
[17:78] <i>This has been Our</i> way with Our Messengers whom We sent before thee; and thou wilt not find any change in Our way.
[17:79] Observe Prayer at the declining and paling of the sun on to the darkness of the night, and the recitation <i>of the Qur</i>’<i>an in Prayer</i> at dawn. Verily, the recitation <i>of the Qur</i>’<i>an</i> at dawn is <i>specially</i> acceptable <i>to God.</i>
[17:80] And wake up for it (the Qur’an) in <i>the latter part of</i> the night as a supererogatory service for thee. It may be that thy Lord will raise thee to an exalted station.
[17:81] And say, ‘O my Lord, make my entry a good entry and <i>then</i> make me come forth with a good forthcoming. And grant me from Thyself a helping power.’
[17:82] And say, ‘Truth has come and falsehood has vanished away. Falsehood does indeed vanish away <i>fast</i>.’
[17:83] And We are <i>gradually</i> revealing of the Qur’an that which is a healing and a mercy to the believers; but it only adds to the loss of the wrongdoers.
[17:84] And when We bestow favour on man, he turns away and goes aside; and when evil touches him, he gives <i>himself</i> up to despair.
[17:85] Say, ‘Everyone acts according to his own way, and your Lord knows full well who is best guided.’
[17:86] And they ask thee concerning the soul. Say, ‘The soul is by the command of my Lord; and of the knowledge <i>thereof</i> you have been given but a little.’
[17:87] And if We pleased, We could certainly take away that which We have revealed to thee <i>and</i> then thou wouldst find in <i>the matter</i> no guardian for thee against Us,
[17:88] Except mercy from thy Lord. Surely, His grace towards thee is great.
[17:89] Say, ‘If mankind and the Jinn gathered together to produce the like of this Qur’an, they could not produce the like thereof, even though they should help one another.’
[17:90] And surely, We have set forth for mankind in various ways all kinds of similitudes in this Qur’an, but most men would reject everything but disbelief.
[17:91] And they say, ‘We will never believe thee until thou cause a spring to gush forth for us from the earth;
[17:92] ‘Or thou have a garden of datepalms and vines, and cause streams to gush forth in the midst thereof in abundance;
[17:93] ‘Or thou cause the heaven to fall upon us in pieces, as thou hast claimed, or thou bring Allah and the angels before us face to face;
[17:94] ‘Or thou have a house of gold or thou ascend up into heaven; and we will not believe in thy ascension until thou send down to us a book that we can read.’ Say, ‘Holy is my Lord! I am not but a man <i>sent as a</i> Messenger.’
[17:95] And nothing has prevented men from believing when the guidance came to them save that they said, ‘Has Allah sent a man <i>as a</i> Messenger?’
[17:96] Say, ‘Had there been in the earth angels walking about in peace and quiet, We should have certainly sent down to them from heaven an angel <i>as a</i> Messenger.’
[17:97] Say, ‘Sufficient is Allah for a Witness between me and you; surely, He knows and sees His servants full well.’
[17:98] And he whom Allah guides, is the <i>only</i> one rightly guided; but <i>as for</i> those whom He allows to perish, thou wilt find for them no helpers beside Him. And on the Day of Resurrection We shall gather them togther on their faces, blind, dumb and deaf. Their abode will be Hell; every time it abates, We shall increase for them the flame.
[17:99] That is their recompense, because they rejected Our Signs and said, ‘What! when we are reduced to bones and broken particles, shall we really be raised up as a new creation?’
[17:100] Have they not seen that Allah Who created the heavens and the earth has the power to create the like of them? And He has appointed for them a term; there is no doubt about it. But the wrongdoers would reject everything but disbelief.
[17:101] Say, ‘Even if you possessed the treasures of the mercy of my Lord, you would surely hold them back for fear of spending, for man is niggardly.’
[17:102] And of a truth We gave Moses nine manifest Signs. So ask <i>then</i> the children of Israel. When he came to them, Pharaoh said to him, ‘I do think thee, O Moses, to be a victim of deception.’
[17:103] He said, ‘Thou knowest well <i>that</i> none has sent down these <i>Signs</i> but the Lord of the heavens and the earth as <i>so many</i> evidences; and I certainly think thee, O Pharaoh, to be <i>a</i> ruined <i>man</i>.’
[17:104] So he resolved to remove them from the land; but We drowned him and those who were with him, all together.
[17:105] And after him We said to the children of Israel, ‘Dwell ye in the land; and when <i>the time of</i> the promise of the latter days comes, We shall bring you together <i>out of various peoples.</i>’ Footnote: And after him We said to the children of Israel, ‘Dwell <b>you</b> in the land; and when <i>the time of</i> the promise of the latter days comes, We shall bring you together <b>once again</b>.
[17:106] And in truth have We sent it down and with truth has it descended. And We have sent thee only as a bearer of good tidings and a Warner.
[17:107] And the Qur’an We have revealed in pieces that thou mayest read it to mankind at intervals, and We have sent it down piecemeal. Footnote: <b>And We divided the Qur’an into parts</b> that <b>you may</b> read it to mankind at intervals, and We have sent it down <b>gradually</b>.
[17:108] Say, “Whether you believe therein or believe not, those to whom knowledge has been given before it, do fall down prostrate on their faces when it is recited to them,
[17:109] “And say, ‘Holy is our Lord. Surely, the promise of our Lord is bound to be fulfilled.’”
[17:110] They fall down on their faces weeping, and it increases humility in them.
[17:111] Say, ‘Call upon Allah or call upon Rahman; <i>by</i> whichever name you call <i>Him</i>, His are the most beautiful names.’ And utter not thy prayer aloud, nor utter it <i>too</i> low, but seek a way between. Footnote: Say, <b>‘Call Allah or call Rahman;</b> <i>by</i> <b>whichever name you pray <i>to Him</i></b>, His are the most beautiful names,’ and utter not thy prayer aloud, nor utter it <i>too</i> low, but seek a way between.
[17:112] And say, ‘All praise belongs to Allah Who has taken unto Himself no son, and Who has no partner in <i>His</i> Kingdom, nor has He anyone to help <i>Him</i> on account of weakness.’ And extol His glory with all glorification.
[18:1] In the name of Allah, the Gracious, the Merciful.
[18:2] All praise belongs to Allah Who has sent down the Book to His servant and has not put therein any crookedness. Footnote: All praise belongs to Allah Who has sent down the Book to His servant and <b>He employed no crookedness in his or in its making.</b> <b>Note:</b> The pronoun <i>hu</i> (<b></b>) in <i>lahu</i> (<b></b>) equally applies to the servant of Allah – the recipient of the Book – and the Book itself. Hence it cannot be translated into English using a pronoun simultaneously applicable to both. If one translates this as ‘God has not placed any crookedness in it,’ it will exclude the Holy Prophet (may peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from this promise of purity. If one translates it as, ‘He has not placed any crookedness in him, then the Book is left out of this sanctity. To resolve this problem we have translated the verse in a different style keeping absolutely loyal to the spirit rather than overemphasizing the letter.
[18:3] <i>He has made it</i> a guardian, that it may give warning of a grievous chastisement from Him, and that it may give the believers who do good deeds the glad tidings that they shall have a good reward,
[18:4] Wherein they shall abide for ever;
[18:5] And that it may warn those who say, ‘ Allah has taken unto Himself a son.’
[18:6] No knowledge have they thereof, nor <i>had</i> their fathers. Grievous is the word that comes from their mouths. They speak naught but a lie.
[18:7] So haply thou wilt grieve thyself to death for sorrow after them if they believe not in this discourse.
[18:8] Verily, We have made all that is on the earth as an ornament for it, that We may try them as to which of them is best in conduct.
[18:9] And We shall make all that is thereon a barren soil.
[18:10] Dost thou think that the People of the Cave and the Inscription were a wonder among Our Signs?
[18:11] When the young men betook themselves for refuge to the Cave and said, ‘Our Lord, bestow on us mercy from Thyself, and provide for us right guidance in our affair.’
[18:12] So We sealed up their ears in the Cave for a number of years. Footnote: So <b>We prevented them from hearing in the Case <i>the news of the outside world</i> for a few years.</b>
[18:13] Then We raised them up that We might know which of the two parties would better reckon the time that they had tarried.
[18:14] We will relate to thee their story with truth: They were young men who believed in their Lord, and We increased them in guidance.
[18:15] And We strengthened their hearts, when they stood up and said, ‘Our Lord is the Lord of the heavens and the earth. Never shall we call upon any god beside Him; <i>if we did</i>, we should indeed have uttered an enormity.
[18:16] ‘These, our people, have taken <i>for worship other</i> gods beside Him. Wherefore do they not bring a clear authority for them? And who is more unjust than he who invents a lie concerning Allah?
[18:17] ‘And <i>now</i> when you have withdrawn from them and from that which they worship beside Allah, then seek refuge in the Cave; your Lord will unfold for you His mercy and will provide for you comfort in <i>this</i> affair of yours.’
[18:18] And thou couldst see the sun, as it rose, move away from their Cave on the right, and when it set, turn away from them on the left; and they were in the spacious hollow thereof. This is among the Signs of Allah. He whom Allah guides is rightly guided; but he whom He adjudges astray, for him thou wilt find no helper <i>or</i> guide. Footnote: And <b>you could</b> see the sun, as it rose, move away from their Cave on the right, and when it set, <b>move across them to the left</b>, and they were in the spacious hollow thereof. This is among the Signs of Allah, He whom Allah guides is rightly guided; but he whom He adjudges astray, for him <b>you will</b> find no helper <i>or</i> guide.
[18:19] Thou mightest deem them awake, whilst they are asleep; and We shall cause them to turn over to the right and to the left, their dog stretching out his forelegs on the threshold. If thou hadst had a look at them, thou wouldst surely have turned away from them in fright, and wouldst surely have been filled with awe of them.
[18:20] And so We raised them up that they might question one another. One of them said, ‘How long have you tarried?’ They said, ‘We have tarried a day or part of a day.’ <i>Others</i> said, ‘Your Lord knows best <i>the time</i> you have tarried. Now send one of you with these silver coins of yours to the city; and let him see which of its <i>inhabitants</i> has the purest food, and let him bring you provisions thereof. And let him be courteous and let him not inform anyone about you.’
[18:21] ‘For, if they should come to know of you, they would stone you or make you return to their religion and then will you never prosper.’ Footnote: ‘For, if they <b>overcome you,</b> they would stone you or make you return to their religion and then you will never prosper.’
[18:22] And thus did We disclose them <i>to the people</i> that they might know that the promise of Allah was true, and that, as to the Hour, there was no doubt about it. <i>And remember the time</i> when people disputed among themselves concerning them, and said, ‘Build over them a building.’ Their Lord knew them best.
