Those who won their point said, ‘We will, surely, build a place of worship over them.’ Footnote: <i>And remember the time</i> when people disputed among themselves concerning them, <b>and <i>some</i> said, ‘Erect a building over them.’</b> <b>Note:</b> ‘Erect a building over them’ means to build a memorial at the site of their caves.
[18:23] <i>Some</i> say, ‘They were three, the fourth was their dog,’ and <i>others</i> say, ‘They were five, the sixth was their dog,’ guessing at random. And <i>yet others</i> say, ‘They were seven, the eighth was their dog.’ Say, ‘My Lord knows best their number. None knows them except a few.’ So argue not concerning them except with arguing <i>that is</i> overpowering, nor seek information about them from any one of them. Footnote: Say, ‘My Lord knows best <b>what their real number was. Very few are those who know regarding them. So do not argue concerning them except for a casual discussion</b>, nor seek information about them from any one of them.’
[18:24] And say not of anything, ‘I am going to do it tomorrow,’
[18:25] Unless Allah should will. And remember thy Lord when thou forgettest, and say, ‘I hope my Lord will guide me to what is even nearer than this to the right path.’
[18:26] And they stayed in their Cave three hundred years, and added nine more.
[18:27] Say, ‘Allah knows best how long they tarried.’ To Him belong the secrets of the heavens and the earth. How Seeing is He! and how Hearing! They have no helper beside Him, and He does not let anyone share in His government. Footnote: Say, ‘Allah knows best how long they tarried <b><i>therein,’</i> To Him belongs the unseen of the heavens and the earth. What a sight He has and what a hearing! There is no friend for them other than He and He does not permit anyone to have a share in His authority.</b>
[18:28] And recite what has been revealed to thee of the Book of thy Lord. There is none who can change His words, and thou wilt find no refuge beside Him.
[18:29] And keep thyself attached to those who call on their Lord, morning and evening, seeking His pleasure; and let not thy eyes pass beyond them, seeking the adornment of the life of the world; and obey not him whose heart We have made heedless of Our remembrance and who follows his evil inclinations, and his case exceeds all bounds.
[18:30] And say, ‘<i>It is</i> the truth from your Lord; wherefore let him who will, believe, and let him who will, disbelieve.’ Verily, We have prepared for the wrongdoers a fire whose <i>flaming</i> canopy shall enclose them. And if they cry for help, they will be helped with water like molten lead which will burn the faces. How dreadful the drink, and how evil is <i>the Fire as</i> a resting place!
[18:31] Verily, those who believe and do good works — surely, We suffer not the reward of those who do good works to be lost.
[18:32] It is these who will have Gardens of Eternity beneath which streams shall flow. They will be adorned therein with bracelets of gold and will wear green garments of fine silk and heavy brocade, reclining therein upon raised couches. How good the reward and how excellent the place of rest!
[18:33] And set forth to them the parable of two men: one of them We provided with two gardens of grapes, and surrounded them with datepalms, and between the two We placed corn-fields.
[18:34] Each of the gardens yielded its fruit <i>in abundance</i>, and failed not the least therein. And in between the two We caused a stream to flow.
[18:35] And he had fruit <i>in abundance.</i> And he said to his companion, arguing <i>boastfully</i> with him, ‘I am richer than thou in wealth and stronger in respect of men.’
[18:36] And he entered his garden while he was wronging his soul. He said, ‘I do not think this will ever perish;
[18:37] ‘And I do not think the Hour will <i>ever</i> come. And even if I am ever brought back to my Lord, I shall, surely, find a better resort than this.’
[18:38] His companion said to him, while he was arguing with him, “Dost thou disbelieve in Him Who created thee from dust, then from a sperm-drop, then fashioned thee into a <i>perfect</i> man? Footnote: His companion said to him, while he was <b>conversing</b> with him, <b>‘Do you</b> disbelieve in Him Who created you from dust,
[18:39] “But <i>as for me</i>, I <i>believe that</i> Allah alone is my Lord, and I will not associate anyone with my Lord.
[18:40] “And why didst thou not say when thou didst enter thy garden: ‘<i>Only</i> that which Allah wills <i>comes to pass.</i> There is no power save in Allah?’ if thou seest me as less than thee in riches and offspring.
[18:41] “Perhaps my Lord will give me something better than thy garden, and will send on it (thy garden) a thunderbolt from heaven so that it will become a bare slippery ground.
[18:42] “Or its water will become sunk <i>in the earth</i> so that thou wilt not be able to find it.”
[18:43] And his fruit was <i>actually</i> destroyed, and he began to wring his hands for what he had spent on it, and it had <i>all</i> fallen down on its trellises. And he said, ‘Would that I had not associated anyone with my Lord!’
[18:44] And he had no party to help him against Allah, nor was he able to defend himself.
[18:45] In such a case protection <i>comes only</i> from Allah, the True. He is the Best in respect of reward, and the Best in respect of consequence. Footnote: <b>At such times the support</b> <i>comes only</i> from Allah, the True.
[18:46] And set forth to them the similitude of the life of this world: it is like the water which We send down from the sky, and the vegetation of the earth is mingled with it, and then it becomes dry grass broken into pieces which the winds scatter. And Allah has power over every thing.
[18:47] Wealth and children are an ornament of the life of this world. But enduring good works are better in the sight of thy Lord in respect of <i>immediate</i> reward, and better in respect of <i>future</i> hope. Footnote: Wealth and children are an <b>adornment</b> of the life of this world.
[18:48] And <i>bethink of</i> the day when We shall remove the mountains, and thou wilt see the <i>nations of the</i> earth march forth <i>against one another</i> and We shall gather them together and shall not leave any one of them behind.
[18:49] And they will be presented to thy Lord, <i>standing</i> in rows: ‘Now have you come to Us as We created you at first. But you thought that We would fix no time for the fulfilment of <i>Our</i> promise to you.’
[18:50] And the Book will be placed <i>before them</i>, and thou wilt see the guilty fearful of that which is therein; and they will say, ‘O woe to us! What kind of a Book is this! It leaves out nothing small or great but has recorded it.’ And they will find all that they did confronting <i>them</i>, and thy Lord does not wrong anyone.
[18:51] And <i>remember the time</i> when We said to the angels, ‘Submit to Adam,’ and they <i>all</i> submitted, except Iblis. He was <i>one</i> of the Jinn; and he disobeyed the command of his Lord. Will you then take him and his offspring for friends instead of Me while they are your enemies? Evil is the exchange for the wrongdoers. Footnote: Will you then take him and his <b>progeny</b> for friends instead of Me while they are your enemies?
[18:52] I did not make them witness the creation of the heavens and the earth, nor their own creation; nor could I take as helpers those who lead <i>people</i> astray.
[18:53] And <i>remember</i> the day when He will say, ‘Call those whom you deemed to be My partners.’ Then they will call on them, but they will not answer them; and We shall place a barrier between them.
[18:54] And the guilty shall see the Fire and realize that they are going to fall therein; and they shall find no way of escape therefrom.
[18:55] And, surely, We have explained in various ways in this Qur’an, for <i>the good of</i> mankind, all <i>kinds of</i> similitudes, but of all things man is most contentious.
[18:56] And nothing hinders people from believing when the guidance comes to them, and from asking forgiveness of their Lord, except <i>that they wait</i> that there should happen to them the precedent of the ancients or that punishment should come upon them face to face. Footnote: And nothing <b>prevented</b> people from believing <b>and seeking</b> forgiveness of their Lord, when guidance <b>came</b> to them, except <i>that they</i> <b>chose to follow the course of the earlier people <i>with the same consequences</i> or awaited the punishment <i>of Allah</i> to take them head on.</b>
[18:57] And We send not the Messengers but as bearers of glad tidings and as Warners. And those who disbelieve contend by means of falsehood so that they may rebut the truth thereby. And they take My Signs and what they are warned of <i>only</i> as a jest.
[18:58] And who is more unjust than he who is reminded of the Signs of his Lord, but turns away from them, and forgets what his hands have sent forward? Verily, We have placed veils over their hearts that they understand it not, and in their ears a deafness. And if thou call them to guidance, they will never accept it.
[18:59] And thy Lord is Most Forgiving, full of mercy. If He were to seize them for what they have earned, then surely He would have hastened the punishment for them. But they have an appointed time from which they will find no refuge.
[18:60] And these towns — We destroyed them when they committed iniquities. And We appointed a fixed time for their destruction.
[18:61] And <i>remember the time</i> when Moses said to his young <i>companion</i>, ‘I will not stop until I reach the junction of the two seas, or I will journey on for ages.’
[18:62] But when they reached the place where the two <i>seas</i> met, they forgot their fish, and it made its way into the sea <i>going away</i> swiftly. Footnote: But when they reached <b>the junction of</b> the two <i>seas</i>, they forgot their fish, and it made its way into the sea <i>going away</i> swiftly.
[18:63] And when they had gone further, he said to his young <i>companion</i>: ‘Bring us our morning meal. Surely, we have suffered much fatigue on account of this journey of ours.’
[18:64] He replied, ‘Didst thou see, when we betook ourselves to the rock for rest, and I forgot the fish — and none but Satan caused me to forget to mention it <i>to thee</i> — it took its way into the sea in a marvellous manner?’ Footnote: He replied, <b>‘Did you</b> see, when we betook ourselves to the rock for rest, and I forgot the fish – and none but Satan caused me to forget to mention it <i>to <b>you</b></i> – it took its way <b>to</b> the sea in a <b>strange</b> manner.
[18:65] He said, ‘That is what we have been seeking.’ So they both returned, retracing their footsteps.
[18:66] Then found they one of Our servants upon whom We had bestowed Our mercy, and whom We had taught knowledge from Ourself.
[18:67] Moses said to him, ‘May I follow thee on condition that thou teach me of the guidance which thou hast been taught?’
[18:68] He replied, ‘Thou canst not keep company with me in patience.
[18:69] ‘And how canst thou be patient about things the knowledge of which thou comprehendest not?’
[18:70] He said, ‘Thou wilt find me, if Allah please, patient and I shall not disobey any command of thine.’ Footnote: He said, <b>‘You will</b> find me, if Allah please, patient and I shall not disobey <b>you in anything.’</b>
[18:71] He said, ‘Well, if thou wouldst follow me, then ask me no questions about anything till I myself speak to thee concerning it.’
[18:72] So they both set out till, when they embarked in a boat, he staved it in. <i>Moses</i> said, ‘Hast thou staved it in to drown those who are in it? Surely, thou hast done an evil thing.’
[18:73] He replied, ‘Did I not tell <i>thee</i> that thou wouldst not be able to keep company with me in patience?’
[18:74] <i>Moses</i> Said, ‘Take me not to task at my forgetting and be not hard on me for this <i>lapse</i> of mine.’
[18:75] So they journeyed on till, when they met a young boy, he slew him. <i>Moses</i> said, ‘Hast thou slain an innocent person without <i>his having slain</i> any one? Surely, thou hast done a hideous thing!’
[18:76] He replied, ‘Did I not tell thee that thou wouldst not be able to keep company with me in patience?’
[18:77] <i>Moses</i> said, ‘If I ask thee concerning anything after this, keep me not in thy company, for <i>then</i> thou shalt have got sufficient excuse from me.’
[18:78] So they went on till, when they came to the people of a town, they asked its people for food, but they refused to make them <i>their</i> guests. And they found therein a wall which was about to fall, and he repaired it. <i>Moses</i> said, ‘If thou hadst desired, thou couldst have taken payment for it.’
[18:79] He said, ‘This is the parting <i>of ways</i> between me and thee. I will now tell thee the meaning of that which thou wast not able to bear with patience:
[18:80] ‘As for the boat, it belonged to <i>certain</i> poor people who worked on the sea; and I desired to damage it, for there was behind them a king, who seized every boat by force.
[18:81] ‘And as for the youth, his parents were believers, and we feared lest he should cause them trouble through rebellion and disbelief.
[18:82] ‘So we desired that their Lord should give them in exchange <i>a child</i> better than him in purity and closer in <i>filial</i> affection.
[18:83] ‘And as for the wall, it belonged to two orphan boys in the town, and beneath it was a treasure belonging to them, and their father had been <i>a</i> righteous <i>man</i>, so thy Lord desired that they should reach their <i>age of</i> full strength and take out their treasure, as a mercy from thy Lord; and I did it not of my own accord. This is the explanation of that which thou wast not able to bear with patience.’
[18:84] And they ask thee about Dhu’l Qarnain. Say, ‘I will certainly recite to you <i>something</i> of his story.’
[18:85] We established him in the earth and gave him the means to <i>accomplish</i> everything.
[18:86] Then he followed a <i>certain</i> way
[18:87] Until, when he reached the setting of the sun, he found it setting in a pool of murky water, and near it he found a people. We said, ‘O Dhu’l Qarnain, either punish them, or treat them with kindness.’
[18:88] He said, ‘As for him who does wrong, we shall certainly punish him; then shall he be brought back to his Lord, Who will punish him with a dreadful punishment.’
[18:89] But as for him who believes and acts righteously, he will have a good reward, and We shall speak to him easy <i>words</i> of Our command.
[18:90] Then <i>indeed</i> he followed <i>another</i> way
[18:91] Until, when he reached the rising of the sun, he found it rising on a people for whom We had made no shelter against it.
[18:92] Thus <i>indeed it was</i>. Verily, We encompassed with Our knowledge <i>all</i> that was with him.
[18:93] Then he followed <i>another</i> way
[18:94] Until, when he reached the place between the two mountains, he found beneath them a people who would scarcely understand a word.
[18:95] They said, ‘O Dhu’l Qarnain, verily, Gog and Magog are creating disorder in the earth; shall we then pay thee tribute on condition that thou set up a barrier between us and them?’
[18:96] He replied, ‘The power with which my Lord has endowed me about this is better, but you may help me with physical strength; I will set up between you and them a rampart.
[18:97] ‘Bring me blocks of iron.’ <i>They did so</i> till, when he had levelled up the space between the two mountain sides, he said, ‘<i>Now</i> blow <i>with your bellows</i>.’ <i>They blew</i> till, when he had made it <i>red as</i> fire, he said, ‘Bring me molten copper that I may pour it thereon.’
[18:98] So they (Gog and Magog) were not able to scale it, nor were they able to dig through it.
[18:99] <i>Thereupon</i> he said, ‘This is a mercy from my Lord. But when the promise of my Lord shall come to pass, He will break it into pieces. And the promise of my Lord is <i>certainly</i> true.’
[18:100] And on that day We shall leave some of them to surge against others, and the trumpet will be blown. Then shall We gather them all together.
[18:101] And on that day We shall present Hell, face to face, to the disbelievers — 
[18:102] Whose eyes were under a veil <i>so as not</i> to <i>heed</i> My warning, and they could not even hear.
[18:103] Do the disbelievers think that they can take My servants as protectors instead of Me? Surely, We have prepared Hell as an entertainment for the disbelievers.
[18:104] Say, ‘Shall We tell you of those who are the greatest losers in respect of their works? —  Footnote: Say, ‘Shall We tell you of those who are the <b>worst losers with regard to their deeds?</b>
[18:105] ‘Those whose labour is <i>all</i> lost in <i>search after things pertaining to</i> the life of this world, and they think that they are doing good works.’
[18:106] Those are they who disbelieve in the Signs of their Lord and in the meeting with Him. So their works are vain, and on the Day of Resurrection We shall give them no weight.
[18:107] That is their reward — Hell; because they disbelieved, and made a jest of My Signs and My Messengers.
[18:108] Surely, those who believe and do good deeds, will have Gardens of Paradise for an abode,
[18:109] Wherein they will abide; they will not desire any change therefrom.
[18:110] Say, ‘If the ocean became ink for the words of my Lord, surely, the ocean would be exhausted before the words of my Lord came to an end, even though We brought the like thereof as <i>further</i> help.’
[18:111] Say, ‘I am only a man like yourselves; <i>but</i> I have received the revelation that your God is only One God. So let him who hopes to meet his Lord do good deeds, and let him join no one in the worship of his Lord.’
[19:1] In the name of Allah, the Gracious, the Merciful.
[19:2] Kaf Ha Ya ‘Ain Sad. Footnote: Thou art sufficient for all and Thou art the True Guide, O All-Knowing, Truthful God!
[19:3] <i>This is</i> an account of the mercy of thy Lord <i>shown</i> to His servant, Zachariah.
[19:4] When he called upon his Lord, a secret calling,
[19:5] He said, ‘My Lord, the bones have indeed waxed feeble in me, and the head glistens with hoariness, but never, my Lord, have I been unblessed in my prayer to Thee.
[19:6] ‘And I fear my relations after me, and my wife is barren. Grant me, therefore, a successor from Thyself,
[19:7] ‘That he may be heir to me and to the House of Jacob. And make him, my Lord, well-pleasing to Thee.’
[19:8] ‘O Zachariah, We give thee glad tidings of a son whose name <i>shall</i> be Yahya‡. We have not made any one before him of that name.’ Footnote: John.
[19:9] He said, ‘My Lord, how shall I have a son when my wife is barren and I have reached <i>the</i> extreme <i>limit of</i> old age?’
[19:10] He said, ‘So it is.’ But thy Lord says, ‘It is easy for Me, and indeed I created thee before, when thou wast nothing.’
[19:11] He said, ‘My Lord, appoint for me a token.’<i>God</i> said, ‘Thy token is that thou shalt not speak to anyone for three full <i>days and</i> nights.’
[19:12] Then he came forth unto his people from the chamber and asked them by signs to glorify <i>God</i> in the morning and in the evening.
[19:13] ‘O Yahya, hold fast the Book.’ And We gave him wisdom while yet a child,
[19:14] And tenderness <i>of heart</i> from Ourself, and purity. And he was pious
[19:15] And dutiful toward his parents. And he was not haughty <i>and</i> rebellious.
[19:16] And peace was on him the day he was born, and the day he died, and <i>peace there will be on him</i> the day he will be raised up to life <i>again.</i>
[19:17] And relate <i>the story of</i> Mary <i>as mentioned</i> in the Book. When she withdrew from her people to a place to the east,
[19:18] And screened herself off from them, then We sent Our angel to her, and he appeared to her in the form of a perfect man.
[19:19] She said, ‘I seek refuge with the Gracious <i>God</i> from thee if indeed thou dost fear <i>Him</i>.’
[19:20] He replied, ‘I am only a Messenger of thy Lord, that I may bestow on thee a righteous son.’
[19:21] She said, ‘How can I have a son when no man has touched me, neither have I been unchaste?’
[19:22] He replied, ‘Thus it is.’ But says thy Lord, ‘It is easy for Me; and <i>We shall do so</i> that We may make him a Sign unto men, and a mercy from Us, and it is a thing decreed.’
[19:23] So she conceived him, and withdrew with him to a remote place.
[19:24] And the pains of childbirth drove her unto the trunk of a palm-tree. She said, ‘O! would that I had died before this and had become a thing quite forgotten!’ Footnote: And the pains of childbirth drove her to the trunk of a <b>date-palm</b>.
[19:25] Then he called her from beneath her, <i>saying</i>, “Grieve not. Thy Lord has placed a rivulet below thee;
[19:26] “And shake towards thyself the trunk of the palm-tree; it will cause fresh ripe dates to fall upon thee.
[19:27] “So eat and drink, and cool <i>thy</i> eye. And if thou seest any man, say, ‘I have vowed a fast to the Gracious <i>God</i>; I will therefore not speak this day to any human being.’”
[19:28] Then she brought him to her people, carrying him. They said, ‘O Mary, thou hast brought forth a strange thing.
[19:29] ‘O sister of Aaron, thy father was not a wicked man nor was thy mother an unchaste woman!’
[19:30] Then she pointed to him. They said, ‘How can we talk to one who is a child in the cradle?’
[19:31] He said, ‘I am a servant of Allah. He has given me the Book, and made me a Prophet;
[19:32] ‘And He has made me blessed wheresoever I may be, and has enjoined upon me Prayer and almsgiving so long as I live;
[19:33] ‘And <i>He has made me</i> dutiful toward my mother, and He has not made me haughty <i>and</i> unblessed.
[19:34] ‘And peace was on me the day I was born, and <i>peace there will be on me</i> the day I shall die, and the day I shall be raised up to life <i>again</i>.’
[19:35] Such was Jesus, son of Mary. <i>This is</i> a statement of the truth about which they doubt.
[19:36] It does not befit <i>the Majesty of</i> Allah to take unto Himself a son. Holy is He. When He decrees a thing, He says to it, ‘Be!’, and it is. Footnote: See the explanation of (<b></b>) (Be! And it is) at page 59 under 3:48. (Publisher)
[19:37] <i>Said Jesus</i>: ‘Surely, Allah is my Lord, and your Lord. So worship Him <i>alone</i>; this is the right path.’
[19:38] But the parties differed among themselves; so woe to those who disbelieve because of the meeting of the great day.
[19:39] How wonderful will their hearing and seeing be on the day when they will come to Us! But today the wrongdoers are in manifest error.
[19:40] And warn them of the day of grief when the matter will be decided. But now they are in <i>a state of</i> carelessness, so they do not believe.
[19:41] It is We Who will inherit the earth and <i>all</i> who are thereon; and to Us will they <i>all</i> be returned.
[19:42] And relate <i>the story of</i> Abraham <i>as mentioned</i> in the Book. He was <i>a</i> truthful <i>man and</i> a Prophet.
[19:43] When he said to his father, ‘O my father, why dost thou worship that which hears not, nor sees, nor can avail thee aught?
[19:44] ‘O my father, there has indeed come to me knowledge such as has not come to thee; so follow me, I will guide thee to an even path.
[19:45] ‘O my father, serve not Satan; surely, Satan is a rebel against the Gracious <i>God.</i>
[19:46] ‘O my father, indeed, I fear lest a punishment from the Gracious <i>God</i> seize thee, and thou become a comrade of Satan.’
[19:47] He replied, ‘Dost thou turn away from my gods, O Abraham? If thou cease not, I shall surely cut off all relations with thee. Now leave me alone for a long while.’
[19:48] <i>Abraham</i> said, ‘Peace be on thee.’ I will ask forgiveness of my Lord for thee. He is indeed gracious to me.
[19:49] ‘And I shall keep away from you and from that which you call upon beside Allah; and I will pray unto my Lord; it may be that, in praying to my Lord, I shall not be disappointed.’
[19:50] So when he had separated himself from them and from that which they worshipped beside Allah, We bestowed on him Isaac and Jacob, and each <i>of them</i> We made a Prophet.
[19:51] And We granted them of Our mercy; and We bestowed on them a true renown.
[19:52] And relate <i>the story of</i> Moses <i>as mentioned</i> in the Book. He was indeed a chosen one; and he was a Messenger, a Prophet.
[19:53] And We called him from the right side of the Mount, and made him draw near <i>to Us</i> for <i>special</i> communion.
[19:54] And We bestowed upon him, out of Our mercy, his brother Aaron as a Prophet.
[19:55] And relate <i>the story of</i> Ishmael <i>as mentioned</i> in the Book. He was indeed strict in <i>keeping his</i> promise. And he was a Messenger, a Prophet.
[19:56] He used to enjoin Prayer and almsgiving on his people, and he was well pleasing to his Lord.
[19:57] And relate <i>the story of</i> Idris <i>as mentioned</i> in the Book. He was <i>a</i> truthful <i>man and</i> a Prophet.
[19:58] And We exalted him to a lofty station.
[19:59] These are the people on whom Allah bestowed His blessings from among the Prophets, of the posterity of Adam, and of <i>the posterity of</i> those whom We carried <i>in the Ark</i> with Noah, and of the posterity of Abraham and Israel; and <i>they are</i> of those whom We guided and chose. When the Signs of the Gracious <i>God</i> were recited unto them, they fell down, prostrating themselves <i>before God</i> and weeping.
[19:60] Then there came after them descendants who neglected Prayer, and followed evil desires. So they will meet with destruction,
[19:61] Except those who repent and believe and do good deeds. These will enter Heaven, and they will not be wronged in the least — 
[19:62] Gardens of Eternity, which the Gracious <i>God</i> has promised to His servants in the unseen. Surely, His promise must come to pass.
[19:63] They will not hear therein anything vain, but only <i>greetings of</i> Peace: and they will have their sustenance therein, morning and evening.
[19:64] Such is the Heaven which We give for an inheritance to those of Our servants who are righteous.
[19:65] ‘And we (angels) do not come down save by the command of thy Lord. To Him belongs all that is before us and all that is behind us and all that is between; and thy Lord is not forgetful.’
[19:66] <i>He is</i> the Lord of the heavens and the earth and of all that is between the two. Serve Him, therefore, and be steadfast in His service. Dost thou know any equal of His?
[19:67] And says man, ‘What! when I am dead, shall I be brought forth alive?’
[19:68] Does not man remember that We created him before, when he was naught?
[19:69] And, by thy Lord, We shall assuredly gather them together, and the satans <i>too</i>; then shall We bring them on their knees around Hell.
[19:70] Then shall We certainly pick out, from every group, those of them who were most stubborn in rebellion against the Gracious <i>God.</i> Footnote: Then shall We certainly <b>drag out</b>, from every group, those of them who were most stubborn in rebellion against the Gracious <i>God</i>.
[19:71] And surely, We know best those most deserving to be burned therein.
[19:72] And there is not one of you but will come to it. This is a fixed decree with thy Lord.
[19:73] Then We shall save the righteous and We shall leave the wrongdoers therein, on their knees.
[19:74] And when Our manifest Signs are recited unto them, the disbelievers say to the believers, ‘Which of the two parties is better in <i>respect of</i> position and <i>makes</i> a more impressive assembly?’
[19:75] And how many generations have We destroyed before them, who were better off in wealth and better in outward show!
[19:76] Say, ‘The Gracious <i>God</i> does give those who are in error long respite until, when they will see that with which they are threatened — whether it be punishment or the Hour — they will realize who is worse in respect of position and who is weaker in forces.
[19:77] ‘And Allah increases in guidance those who follow guidance. And the good works that endure are best in sight of thy Lord as reward, and best as resort.’
[19:78] Hast thou then seen him who disbelieves in Our Signs, and says, ‘I shall certainly be given wealth and children?’
[19:79] Has he become acquainted with the unseen or has he taken a promise from the Gracious <i>God</i>?
[19:80] Nay! We shall note down what he says and We shall greatly prolong for him the punishment.
[19:81] And We shall inherit of him all that of which he talks, and he shall come to Us all alone.
[19:82] And they have taken <i>other</i> gods beside Allah, that they may be <i>a source of</i> power for them.
[19:83] Not at all! They will reject their worship, and become their opponents.
[19:84] Seest thou not that We have sent satans against the disbelievers goading them on <i>to acts of disobedience</i>?
[19:85] So be not thou in haste with regard to them; We are keeping full account of their <i>doings</i>.
[19:86] <i>Remember</i> the day when We shall gather the righteous before the Gracious <i>God</i> as <i>honoured</i> guests<i>.</i>
[19:87] And We shall drive the guilty to Hell like a herd <i>of thirsty camels</i>. Footnote: And We shall drive the guilty to Hell like a herd <b>to a watering place</b>.
[19:88] None will have the power of intercession save he who has received a promise from the Gracious <i>God</i>.
[19:89] And they say, ‘The Gracious <i>God</i> has taken unto Himself a son.’
[19:90] Assuredly, you have done a most monstrous thing!
[19:91] The heavens might well-nigh burst thereat, and the earth cleave asunder, and the mountains fall down in pieces,
[19:92] Because they ascribe a son to the Gracious <i>God.</i>
[19:93] Whereas it becomes not the Gracious <i>God</i> to take unto Himself a son.
[19:94] There is none in the heavens and the earth but he shall come to the Gracious <i>God</i> as a bondman.
[19:95] Verily, He comprehends them <i>by His knowledge</i> and has numbered them all fully.
[19:96] And each of them shall come to Him singly on the Day of Resurrection.
[19:97] Those who believe and do good deeds — the Gracious <i>God</i> will create love in their <i>hearts</i>.
[19:98] So We have made it (the Qur’an) easy in thy tongue that thou mayest give thereby good tidings to the righteous, and warn thereby a people given to contention.
[19:99] And how many a generation have We destroyed before them! Canst thou see a single one of them, or hear <i>even</i> a whisper of them?
[20:1] In the name of Allah, the Gracious, the Merciful.
[20:2] Ta Ha. Footnote: O Perfect Man!
[20:3] We have not sent down the Qur’an to thee that thou shouldst be distressed,
[20:4] But as an exhortation for him who fears <i>God</i>,
[20:5] <i>And</i> a revelation from Him Who created the earth and the high heavens.
[20:6] <i>He is</i> the Gracious <i>God Who</i> has settled Himself on the Throne.
[20:7] To Him belongs whatsoever is in the heavens and whatsoever is in the earth, and whatsoever is between them, and whatsoever is beneath the moist subsoil.
[20:8] And if thou speakest aloud, <i>it makes no difference</i>, for He knows the secret <i>thought</i> and <i>what is yet</i> more hidden.
[20:9] Allah — there is no God but He. His are the most beautiful names.
[20:10] And has the story of Moses come to thee?
[20:11] When he saw a fire, he said to his family, ‘Tarry ye, I perceive a fire; perhaps I may bring you a brand therefrom or find guidance at the fire.’
[20:12] And when he came to it, he was called <i>by a voice</i>, ‘O Moses, Footnote: And when he came to it, <b>it was announced,</b> ‘O, Moses.
[20:13] ‘Verily, I am thy Lord. So take off thy shoes; for thou art in the sacred Valley of Tuwa.
[20:14] ‘And I have chosen thee; so hearken to what is revealed.
[20:15] ‘Verily, I am Allah; there is no God beside Me. So serve Me, and observe Prayer for My remembrance.
[20:16] ‘Surely, the Hour is coming; I am going to manifest it, that every soul may be recompensed for its endeavour. Footnote: Surely, the Hour <b>will come; I may reveal it,</b> that every soul may be recompensed for its endeavour.
[20:17] ‘So let not him who believes not therein and follows his own evil inclinations, turn thee away therefrom, lest thou perish.
[20:18] ‘And what is that in thy right hand, O Moses?’
[20:19] He replied, ‘This is my rod, I lean on it, and beat down therewith leaves for my sheep, and I have <i>also</i> other uses for it.’
[20:20] He said, ‘Cast it down, O Moses.’
[20:21] So he cast it down, and behold! it was a serpent running.
[20:22] <i>God</i> said, ‘Catch hold of it, and fear not. We shall restore it to its former condition.
[20:23] ‘And draw thy hand close under thy armpit. It shall come forth white, without any disease — another Sign, Footnote: <b>And press your hand close to your side.</b> It shall come forth white, without <b>blemish</b> – another Sign.
[20:24] ‘That We may show thee some of Our greater Signs.
[20:25] ‘Go thou to Pharaoh; he has indeed exceeded <i>all</i> bounds.’
[20:26] <i>Moses</i> said, ‘My Lord, open out for me my breast, Footnote: <b>He</b> said, ‘My Lord! <b>Open up</b> for me my <b>heart.</b>
[20:27] ‘And ease for me my task,
[20:28] ‘And loose the knot of my tongue, Footnote: ‘And <b>untie</b> the knot of my tongue.’
[20:29] ‘That they may understand my speech,
[20:30] ‘And grant me a helper from my family — 
[20:31] ‘Aaron, my brother;
[20:32] ‘Increase my strength with him,
[20:33] ‘And make him share my task,
[20:34] ‘That we may glorify Thee much,
[20:35] ‘And remember Thee much.
[20:36] ‘Thou possessest full knowledge of us.’
[20:37] <i>God</i> said, “Granted is thy prayer, O Moses!
[20:38] “And We did indeed confer a favour upon thee at another time <i>also</i>,
[20:39] “When We revealed to thy mother what was an <i>important</i> revelation, <i>saying</i>,
[20:40] “‘Put him in the ark, and throw it into the river, then the river will cast it on to the bank, <i>and one who is</i> an enemy to Me and also an enemy to him will take him up.’ And I wrapped thee with love from Me; and <i>this I did</i> that thou mightest be reared before My eye.
[20:41] “When thy sister walked along and said, ‘Shall I guide you to one who will take charge of him?’ So We restored thee to thy mother that her eye might be cooled and she might not grieve. And thou didst kill a man, but We delivered thee from sorrow. Then We proved thee in various ways. And thou didst tarry several years among the people of Midian. Then thou camest up to the standard, O Moses.
[20:42] “And I have chosen thee for Myself.
[20:43] “Go, thou and thy brother, with My Signs, and slacken not in remembering Me.
[20:44] “Go, both of you, to Pharaoh, for he has transgressed <i>all</i> bounds.
[20:45] “But speak to him a gentle speech that he might possibly heed or fear.” Footnote: <b>‘And address him both of you, with gentle words</b> that he might possibly heed or fear.’
[20:46] They replied, ‘Our Lord, we fear lest he commit some excess against us, or exceed <i>all</i> bounds in transgression.’
[20:47] <i>God</i> said, “Fear not; for I am with you both. I hear and I see.
[20:48] “So go ye both to him and say, ‘We are the Messengers of thy Lord; so let the children of Israel go with us; and afflict them not. We have indeed brought thee a Sign from thy Lord; and peace shall be on him who follows the guidance;
[20:49] ‘It has indeed been revealed to us that punishment shall come on him who rejects and turns away.’”
[20:50] <i>Pharaoh</i> said, ‘Who then is the Lord of you two, O Moses?’
[20:51] He said, ‘Our Lord is He Who gave unto everything its <i>proper</i> form <i>and</i> then guided <i>it to its proper function</i>.’
[20:52] <i>Pharaoh</i> said, ‘What then will be the fate of the former generations?’
[20:53] He said, ‘The knowledge thereof is with my Lord <i>recorded</i> in a Book. My Lord neither errs nor forgets.’
[20:54] <i>It is He</i> Who has made the earth for you a cradle, and has caused pathways for you to run through it; and Who sends down rain from the sky, and thereby We bring forth various kinds of vegetation.
[20:55] Eat ye and pasture your cattle. Verily, in this are Signs for those who are endued with reason.
[20:56] From it have We created you, and into it shall We cause you to return, and from it shall We bring you forth once more.
[20:57] And We did show him (Pharaoh) Our Signs, all of them; but he rejected <i>them</i> and refused <i>to believe</i>.
[20:58] He said, ‘Hast thou come to us, O Moses, to drive us out of our land by thy magic?
[20:59] ‘But we shall assuredly bring thee magic the like thereof; so make an appointment between us and thyself which we shall not fail to keep — neither we nor thou — at a place alike <i>for us both</i>.’
[20:60] Moses said, ‘Your appointment shall be for the day of the Festival, and let the people be assembled when the sun is risen high.’
[20:61] Then Pharaoh withdrew and concerted his plan and then came <i>to the place of appointment</i>. Footnote: Then Pharaoh <b>turned away and mustered all his tricks, then he came <i>in keeping with the appointment.</i></b>
[20:62] Moses said to them, ‘Woe to you; forge not a lie against Allah, lest He destroy you by some punishment; and surely, he who forges a lie shall perish.’
[20:63] Then they argued their affair among themselves and conferred in secret.
[20:64] They said, ‘Certainly these two are magicians, who desire to drive you out from your land by their magic and to destroy your best traditions.
[20:65] ‘Concert, therefore, your plan and then come forward arrayed. And, surely, he who gains ascendancy this day shall prosper.’
[20:66] They said, ‘O Moses, either do thou throw <i>first</i>, or we shall be the first to throw.’
[20:67] He said, ‘Nay, throw ye.’ Then lo! their cords and their staves appeared to him, by their magic, as though they ran <i>about</i>.
[20:68] And Moses conceived a fear in his mind.
[20:69] We said, ‘Fear not, for thou wilt have the upper hand.
[20:70] ‘And throw that which is in thy right hand; it will swallow that which they have wrought, for that which they have wrought is only a magician’s trick. And a magician shall not thrive, come where he may.’
[20:71] Then the magicians were made to fall down prostrate. They said, ‘We believe in the Lord of Aaron and Moses.’
[20:72] <i>Pharaoh</i> said, ‘Do you believe in him before I give you leave? He must be your chief who has taught you magic. I will therefore surely cut off your hands and your feet alternately, and I will surely crucify you on the trunks of palm-trees; and you shall know which of us is severer and more abiding in punishment.’
[20:73] They said, ‘We shall not prefer thee to the manifest Signs that have come to us, nor <i>shall we prefer thee</i> to Him Who has created us. So decree what thou wilt decree; thou canst only decree concerning this present life.
[20:74] ‘Surely we have believed in our Lord that He may forgive us our sins and <i>forgive us</i> the magic which thou didst force us <i>to use</i>. And Allah is the Best and the Most Abiding.’
[20:75] Verily, he who comes to his Lord a sinner — for him is Hell; he shall neither die therein nor live.
[20:76] But he who comes to Him as a believer having done good deeds, for such are the highest ranks — 
[20:77] Gardens of Eternity, beneath which rivers flow; they will abide therein <i>for ever</i>. And that is the recompense of those who keep themselves pure.
[20:78] And We sent a revelation to Moses, <i>saying</i>, ‘Take away My servants by night, and strike for them a dry path through the sea. Thou wilt not be afraid of being overtaken, nor wilt thou have <i>any other</i> fear.’
[20:79] Then Pharaoh pursued them with his hosts, and there overwhelmed them of the waters of the sea that which overwhelmed them.
[20:80] And Pharaoh led his people astray and did not guide them aright.
[20:81] ‘O children of Israel, We delivered you from your enemy, and We made a covenant with you on the right side of the Mount, and We sent down on you Manna and Salwa.
[20:82] ‘Eat of the good things that We have provided for you, and transgress not therein, lest My wrath descend upon you; and he on whom My wrath descends shall perish;
[20:83] ‘But surely I am forgiving to those who repent and believe and do good deeds, and then stick to guidance.
[20:84] ‘And what has hastened thee away from thy people, O Moses?’
[20:85] He said, ‘They are <i>closely</i> <i>following</i> in my footsteps and I have <i>hastened to Thee, my Lord, that</i> <i>Thou mightest be pleased.’</i> Footnote: He said, ‘They are <b><i>close upon</i> my tracks</b> and I have hastened to <b>You</b>, my Lord, that <b>You may</b> be pleased.’
[20:86] <i>God</i> said, ‘We have tried thy people in thy absence, and the Samiri has led them astray.’
[20:87] So Moses returned to his people indignant and sad. He said, ‘O my people, did not your Lord promise you a gracious promise? Did, then, the appointed time appear too long to you, or did you desire that wrath should descend upon you from your Lord, that you broke <i>your</i> promise to me?’
[20:88] They said, ‘We have not broken <i>our</i> promise to thee of our own accord; but we were laden with loads of people’s ornaments and we threw them away, and likewise did the Samiri cast.’
[20:89] Then he produced for them a calf — an image producing a lowing sound. And they said, ‘This is your God, and the God of Moses.’ So he gave up <i>the religion of Moses</i>. Footnote: Then he produced for them a calf – <b>a mere body which emitted</b> a lowing sound. <b>Then <i>he and his companions</i> said, ‘This is your god, and the god of Moses but he forgot <i>to mention it to you.’</i></b>
[20:90] Could they not see that it returned to them no answer, and had no power to do them either harm or good?
[20:91] And Aaron had said to them before this, ‘O my people, you have only been tried by means of it (the calf). And surely, the Gracious <i>God</i> is your Lord; so follow me and obey my command.’
[20:92] They replied, ‘We shall not cease to worship it until Moses return to us.’
[20:93] <i>Moses</i> said, “O Aaron, what hindered thee, when thou didst see them gone astray,
[20:94] ‘From following me? Hast thou then disobeyed my command?’
[20:95] He answered, “O son of my mother seize me not by my beard, nor by <i>the hair of</i> my head. I feared lest thou shouldst say, ‘Thou hast caused a division among the children of Israel, and didst not wait for my word.’” Footnote: <b>Note:</b> The expression ‘seize me not by my beard, nor by (the hair of) my head’ should not be taken literally. It may simply mean: <b>do not humiliate me.</b>
[20:96] <i>Moses</i> said, ‘And what hast thou to say, O Samiri?’
[20:97] He said, ‘I perceived what they perceived not. I <i>only</i> partly received the impress of the Messenger, but that <i>too</i> I cast away. Thus it is that my mind commended to me.’
[20:98] <i>Moses</i> said, “Go away. It shall be thine to say throughout thy life, ‘Touch <i>me</i> not;’ and there is a promise of <i>punishment</i> for thee which shall not fail to be fulfilled about thee. Now look at thy god of which thou hast become a devoted worshipper. We will certainly burn it and then scatter it away into the sea.”

[20:119] ‘It is <i>provided</i> for thee that thou wilt not hunger therein, nor wilt thou be naked.
[20:120] ‘And that thou wilt not thirst therein, nor wilt thou be exposed to the sun.’
[20:121] But Satan whispered evil suggestions to him; he said, ‘O Adam, shall I lead thee to the tree of eternity and to a kingdom that never decays?’
[20:122] Then they both ate thereof, so that their shame became manifest to them, and they began to stick the leaves of the garden together over themselves. And Adam observed not the commandment of his Lord, so his life became miserable. Footnote: They both ate thereof, <b>so their inherent weakness became exposed to them. So they started covering themselves with the leaves from the garden. And Adam disobeyed his Lord and deviated from the path.</b> <b>Note:</b> Most translators have taken the scenario too literally while there is enough evidence within the text to rule out a literal application. The sin referred to is obviously related to an internal faltering as indicated by the part of the verse which declares that (<b></b>) <i>sauatuhuma</i> (their weakness) became known to them. If it was a bodily nakedness how could they have remained unaware of their nakedness from the time of their birth to the time of the said incident? It is evident, therefore, that a literal meaning is wrongfully attributed to the Holy Qur’an. The word <i>sau’a</i> (<b></b>) primarily applies to acts of shame and evil propensities. At the time of faltering the falterer discovers to his horror his own hidden weaknesses. This weakness is psychological and internal, relate to mind and heart, and cannot be covered and concealed by sticking leaves over one’s body. So in the context of this error, whatever it was, which Adam and Eve committed, coverage can only mean seeking forgiveness from Allah and (seeking protection from Allah). As such leaves of <i>‘jannah’</i> (<b></b>) (garden) must be understood metaphorically to mean seeking shelter under Allah’s forgiveness and that is exactly what Adam did according to the Qur’an where it is clearly mentioned that God Himself taught him those words which would rid him of the effects of his error and in response to those words God turned to him with mercy and forgiveness.

[20:125] ‘But whosoever will turn away from My Reminder, his will be a strait life, and on the Day of Resurrection We shall raise him up blind.’
[20:126] He will say, ‘My Lord, why hast Thou raised me up blind, while I possessed sight <i>before</i>?’

[21:54] They replied, ‘We found our fathers worshipping them.’
[21:55] He said, ‘Indeed, you yourselves as well as your fathers have been in manifest error.’
[21:56] They said, ‘Is it <i>really</i> the truth that thou hast brought us, or art thou one of those who jest?’
[21:57] He replied, ‘Nay, your Lord is the Lord of the heavens and the earth, He Who made them; and I am one of those who bear witness to that.

[21:59] So he broke them to pieces, <i>all</i> except the chief of them, that they might return to it <i>for enquiry</i>.
[21:60] They said, ‘Who has done this to our gods? Surely, he must be a wrongdoer.’
[21:61] They said, ‘We heard a young man speak <i>ill</i> of them; he is called Abraham.’
[21:62] They said, ‘Then bring him before the eyes of the people, that they may bear witness.’
[21:63] <i>Then</i> they said <i>to Abraham</i>, ‘Is it thou who hast done this to our gods, O Abraham?’
[21:64] He replied, ‘Aye, somebody has surely done this. Here is their chief. But ask them if they can speak.’ Footnote: He replied, ‘Aye, somebody has surely done this. Here is the chief <b><i>suspect</i></b>. Ask them if they <b>are capable of speaking</b>.’ <b>Note:</b> Some translators avoid literal translation of this verse fearing that this would present Abraham as a liar. Obviously it was not the big idols who had smashed the smaller ones but it was Abraham himself who had done it. Therefore attributing the statement to Abraham that ‘here is the chief,’ would be tantamount to attributing an obvious lie to Abraham. It should be noted, however, that it was not a misstatement but a powerful style of argument. Sometimes a thing is too obvious for anybody to believe and a statement to that effect is never understood as a willful attempt to mislead others but considered an exposition of the inherent absurdity of a situation. We believe that Abraham did make that statement without the slightest intention of misleading them but only by way of a powerful argument against the falsity of their belief. This is exactly how they took it. Having heard Abraham, none of them retorted by calling him a liar. But according to the Holy Qur’an they were introspectively forced to realize the folly of their belief. This is made clear in the following verses (see verses 65 to 68). Again, it should be remembered that before this incident Abraham himself had mentioned in public his resolve to smash their idols (see verse 58).

And We cause what We will to remain in the wombs for an appointed term; then We bring you forth as babes; then <i>We rear you</i> that you may attain to your <i>age of</i> full strength. And there are some of you who are caused to die <i>prematurely</i>, and there are others among you who are driven to the worst part of life <i>with the result</i> that they know nothing after <i>having had</i> knowledge. And thou seest the earth lifeless, but when We send down water thereon, it stirs and swells, and grows every kind of beauteous vegetation. Footnote: We <b>have delivered you as a child so that <i>afterwards</i> you may reach</b> your age of full <b>maturity</b>. And there are <b>those</b> among you who <b>die</b> and there are others among you who are <b>made to recede to the age of senility</b> <i>with the result</i> that they know nothing after <i>having had</i> knowledge. <b>Note:</b> The word ‘recede’ is used to indicate that as in the beginning the child is helpless and incapable of taking care of himself so also a man at an overly advanced age returns to a similar state. This connotation is supported by the verse ‘<i>wa man nu’ammirhu nunakkishu fil khalq</i>’ (<b></b>) (36:69)
[22:7] That is because Allah is the Truth, and that it is He Who brings the dead to life, and that He has power over all things;
[22:8] And because the Hour will <i>certainly</i> come, there is no doubt about it, and because Allah will raise up those who are in the graves.
[22:9] And among men there is he who disputes concerning Allah without knowledge and without guidance and without an enlightening Book,
[22:10] Turning his side <i>disdainfully</i>, that he may lead <i>men</i> astray from the way of Allah. For him is disgrace in this world; and on the Day of Resurrection We shall make him taste the punishment of burning.
[22:11] This is because of what thy hands have sent on before, and Allah is not unjust to <i>His</i> servants.
[22:12] And among men there is he who serves Allah, <i>standing as it were</i> on the verge. Then if good befall him, he is content therewith; and if there befall him a trial, he returns to his <i>former</i> way. He loses in this world as well as in the Hereafter. That is an evident loss. Footnote: And among men there is he who <b>worships Allah on the borderline <i>of belief</i>, then if good attends him,</b> he is content therewith; and if there befall him a trial, <b>he turns away <i>from Allah.</i></b>
[22:13] He calls beside Allah on that which can neither harm him, nor benefit him. That is indeed straying far away.
[22:14] He calls on him whose harm is nearer than his benefit. Evil indeed is the patron, and evil indeed the associate.
[22:15] Verily, Allah will cause those who believe and do good deeds to enter Gardens beneath which rivers flow; surely Allah does what He will.
[22:16] Whoso thinks that Allah will not help him (the Prophet) in this world and the Hereafter, let him, <i>if he can</i>, find a way to heaven, and let him cut off <i>the divine help</i>. Then let him see if his device can remove that which enrages <i>him</i>.
[22:17] And thus have We sent it (the Qur’an) down as manifest Signs, and surely Allah guides whom He will.
[22:18] <i>As to</i> those who believe, and the Jews, and the Sabians, and the Christians, and the Magians and the idolaters, verily, Allah will judge between them on the Day of Resurrection; surely Allah is Witness over all things.
[22:19] Hast thou not seen that to Allah submits whosoever is in the heavens and whosoever is in the earth, and the sun, and the moon, and the stars, and the mountains, and the trees, and the beasts, and many of mankind? But there are many who become deserving of punishment. And whomsoever Allah disgraces, none can raise him to honour. Verily, Allah does what He pleases.
[22:20] These two are two disputants who dispute concerning their Lord. As for those who disbelieve, garments of fire will be cut out for them; <i>and</i> boiling water will be poured down on their heads,
[22:21] Whereby that which is in their bellies, and <i>their</i> skins too, will be melted;
[22:22] And for them there will be maces of iron <i>with which to punish them.</i>
[22:23] Whenever they will seek to get out of it from anguish, they will be turned back into it: and <i>it will be said to them</i>, ‘Taste ye the punishment of burning!’
[22:24] But Allah will cause those who believe and do good deeds to enter Gardens beneath which rivers flow. They will be adorned therein with bracelets of gold, and with pearls; and their raiment therein will be of silk.
[22:25] And they will be guided to pure speech, and they will be guided to the path of the Praiseworthy <i>God</i>. Footnote: And they will be guided <b>only to virtuous</b> speech, and they will be guided to the path of the Praiseworthy <i>God</i>.
[22:26] <i>As to</i> those who disbelieve, and hinder <i>men</i> from the way of Allah and from the Sacred Mosque, which We have appointed equally for all men, be they dwellers therein or visitors from the desert, and whoso seeks wrongfully to deviate therein <i>from the right path</i> — We shall cause them to taste of a grievous punishment.
[22:27] And <i>remember the time</i> when We assigned to Abraham the site of the House <i>and said</i>, ‘Associate not anything with Me, and keep My House clean for those who perform the circuits, and those who stand up and those who bow down <i>and</i> fall prostrate <i>in Prayers</i>;
[22:28] ‘And proclaim unto mankind the Pilgrimage. They will come to thee on foot, and on every lean camel, coming by every distant track,
[22:29] ‘That they may witness <i>its</i> benefits for them and may mention the name of Allah, during the appointed days, over the quadrupeds of <i>the class of</i> cattle that He has provided for them. Then eat ye thereof and feed the distressed, the needy.
[22:30] ‘Then let them accomplish their needful acts of cleansing, and fulfill their vows, and go around the Ancient House.’ Footnote: ‘Then let them accomplish <b>the task of cleansing themselves,</b> and fulfil their vows, and go around the Ancient house.’
[22:31] That is <i>God’s commandment.</i> And whoso honours the sacred things of Allah, it will be good for him with his Lord. And cattle are made lawful to you but not that which has been announced to you. Shun therefore the abomination of idols, and shun all words of untruth, Footnote: Shun therefore the abomination of idols, <b>and shun false speech.</b>
[22:32] Remaining ever inclined to Allah, not associating anything with Him. And whoso associates anything with Allah, falls, as it were, from a height, and the birds snatch him up, or the wind blows him away to a distant place.
[22:33] That <i>is so</i>. And whoso respects the sacred Signs of Allah — that indeed <i>proceeds</i> from the righteousness of hearts.
[22:34] In them (offerings) are benefits for you for an appointed term, then their place of sacrifice is at the Ancient House.
[22:35] And to every people We appointed rites of sacrifice, that they might mention the name of Allah over the quadrupeds of <i>the class of</i> cattle that He has provided for them. So your God is One God; therefore submit ye <i>all</i> to Him. And give thou glad tidings to the humble,
[22:36] Whose hearts are filled with fear when Allah is mentioned, and who patiently endure whatever befalls them, and who observe Prayer, and spend out of what We have provided for them. Footnote: Whose hearts are filled with <b>awe</b> when Allah is mentioned, and who patiently endure whatever befalls them, and who observe Prayer, and spend out of what We have provided for them.
[22:37] And among the sacred Signs of Allah We have appointed for you the sacrificial camels. In them there is <i>much</i> good for you. So mention the name of Allah over them as they stand tied up in lines. And when they fall down <i>dead</i> on their sides, eat thereof and feed him who is <i>needy but</i> contented and him who supplicates. Thus have We subjected them to you, that you may be thankful.
[22:38] Their flesh reaches not Allah, nor does their blood, but it is your righteousness that reaches Him. Thus has He subjected them to you, that you may glorify Allah for His guiding you. And give glad tidings to those who do good.
[22:39] Surely, Allah defends those who believe. Surely, Allah loves not any one who is perfidious <i>or</i> ungrateful.
[22:40] Permission <i>to fight</i> is given to those against whom war is made, because they have been wronged — and Allah indeed has power to help them — 
[22:41] Those who have been driven out from their homes unjustly only because they said, ‘Our Lord is Allah’ — And if Allah did not repel some men by means of others, there would surely have been pulled down cloisters and churches and synagogues and mosques, wherein the name of Allah is oft commemorated. And Allah will surely help one who helps Him. Allah is indeed Powerful, Mighty — 
[22:42] Those who, if We establish them in the earth, will observe Prayer and pay the Zakat and enjoin good and forbid evil. And with Allah rests the final issue of all affairs.
[22:43] And if they accuse thee of falsehood, even so, before them, the people of Noah and <i>the tribes of</i> ‘Ad and Thamud <i>also</i> accused <i>their Prophets</i> of falsehood.

[22:45] And the inhabitants of Midian. And Moses <i>too</i> was accused of falsehood. But I gave respite to the disbelievers; then I seized them, and how <i>terrible</i> was the change I <i>effected in them</i>!
[22:46] And how many a city have We destroyed, while it was given to wrongdoing, so that it is fallen down on its roofs; and <i>how many a</i> deserted well and lofty castle!
[22:47] Have they not travelled in the land, so that they may have hearts wherewith to understand, or ears wherewith to hear? But <i>the fact is that</i> it is not the eyes that are blind, but it is the hearts which are in the breasts that are blind.
[22:48] And they ask thee to hasten on punishment, but Allah will never break His promise. And verily, a day with thy Lord is as a thousand years of your reckoning.
[22:49] And how many a city there is to which I gave respite, while it was given to wrongdoing. Then I seized it, and unto Me is the return.
[22:50] Say, ‘O mankind, I am but a plain Warner to you.’
[22:51] Those who believe and do good works, for them is forgiveness and an honourable provision.

[22:53] Never sent We a Messenger or a Prophet before thee, but when he sought <i>to attain what he aimed at</i>, Satan put <i>obstacles</i> in <i>the way of</i> what he sought after. But Allah removes <i>the obstacles</i> that are placed by Satan. Then Allah firmly establishes His Signs. And Allah is All-Knowing, Wise.
[22:54] <i>He permits this</i> that He may make <i>the obstacles</i> which Satan puts <i>in the way of the Prophets</i> a trial for those in whose hearts is a disease and those whose hearts are hardened — and surely the wrongdoers are gone far <i>in error</i> — 
[22:55] And that those to whom knowledge has been given may know that it is the truth from thy Lord, so that they may believe therein and their hearts may become lowly unto Him. And surely Allah guides those who believe to the right path.

[22:57] The kingdom on that day shall be Allah’s. He will judge between them. So those who believe and do good deeds will be in Gardens of Delight.
[22:58] But those who disbelieve and reject Our Signs, will have an humiliating punishment.
[22:59] And those who leave their homes for the cause of Allah, and are then slain or die, Allah will surely provide for them a goodly provision. And surely Allah is the Best of providers.
[22:60] He will surely cause them to enter a place with which they will be well pleased. And Allah is indeed All-Knowing, Forbearing.
[22:61] That <i>shall be so</i>. And whoso retaliates with the like of that with which he has been afflicted and is then transgressed against, Allah will surely help him. Allah is indeed the Effacer of sins <i>and</i> is Forgiving.
[22:62] That is because Allah causes the night to enter into the day, and causes the day to enter into the night, and because Allah is All-Hearing, All-Seeing.
[22:63] That is because it is Allah Who is the Truth, and that which they call on beside Him is falsehood, and because Allah is the High, the Great.
[22:64] Hast thou not seen that Allah sends down water from the sky and the earth becomes green? Allah is indeed the Knower of subtleties, the All-Aware. Footnote: Allah is indeed <b>Exquisite, All-Aware.</b>

[22:66] Hast thou not seen that Allah has subjected to you whatever is in the earth, and the ships that sail through the sea by His command? And He withholds the rain from falling on the earth save by His leave. Surely, Allah is Compassionate <i>and</i> Merciful to men. Footnote: And <b>He prevents heavenly bodies from falling upon earth except by His leave.</b> Surely, Allah is Compassionate <i>and</i> Merciful to men. <b>Note:</b> It is likely that the word ‘leave’ applies to falling meteors, and other heavenly bodies which constantly bombard the earth.
[22:67] And He it is Who gave you life, then He will cause you to die, then will He give you life <i>again</i>. Surely, man is most ungrateful.
[22:68] To every people have We appointed ways of worship which they observe; so let them not dispute with thee in the matter; and invite thou to thy Lord, for surely, thou followest the right guidance.

[22:70] ‘Allah will judge between you on the Day of Resurrection concerning that about which you used to differ.’
[22:71] Dost thou not know that Allah knows whatsoever is in the heavens and the earth? Surely, it is <i>all preserved</i> in a Book, <i>and</i> that is easy for Allah.
[22:72] And they worship beside Allah that for which He has sent down no authority, and that of which they have no knowledge. And for those that do wrong there is no helper.
[22:73] And when Our clear Signs are recited unto them, thou wilt notice a denial on the faces of those who disbelieve. They would well-nigh attack those who recite Our Signs to them. Say, ‘Shall I tell you of something worse than that? <i>It is</i> the Fire! Allah has promised it to those who disbelieve. And a vile destination it is!’
[22:74] O men, a similitude is set forth, so listen to it. Surely, those on whom you call instead of Allah cannot create <i>even</i> a fly, though they combine together for the purpose. And if the fly should snatch away anything from them, they cannot recover it therefrom. Weak indeed are <i>both</i> the seeker and the sought.
[22:75] They esteem not Allah with the estimation which is His due. Surely, Allah is Powerful, Mighty.
[22:76] Allah chooses <i>His</i> Messengers from among angels, and from among men. Surely, Allah is All- Hearing, All-Seeing. Footnote: Allah chooses <b>Messengers</b> from among angels, and from among men.

[22:78] O ye who believe! bow down and prostrate yourselves in Prayer, and worship your Lord, and do good deeds that you may prosper.
[22:79] And strive in the cause of Allah as it behoves you to strive for it. He has chosen you, and has laid no hardship upon you in religion; <i>so follow</i> the faith of your father Abraham; He named you Muslims <i>both</i> before and in this <i>Book</i>, so that the Messenger may be a witness over you, and that you may be witnesses over mankind. Therefore observe Prayer and pay the Zakat, and hold fast to Allah. He is your Master. An excellent Master and an excellent Helper!
[23:1] In the name of Allah, the Gracious, the Merciful.

[23:6] And who guard their chastity —

[23:8] But those who seek <i>anything</i> beyond that are the transgressors —

[23:13] Verily, We created man from an extract of clay;
[23:14] Then We placed him as a drop of sperm in a safe depository;
[23:15] Then We fashioned the sperm into a clot; then We fashioned the clot into a <i>shapeless</i> lump; then We fashioned bones out of this <i>shapeless</i> lump; then We clothed the bones with flesh; then We developed it into another creation. So blessed be Allah, the Best of creators.
[23:16] Then after that you must surely die.
[23:17] Then on the Day of Resurrection will you be raised up.
[23:18] And We have created above you seven <i>heavens</i> lying one above the other, and We are never neglectful of the creation.

[23:24] And We did send Noah to his people, and he said, ‘O my people, serve Allah. You have no God other than Him. Will you not then be righteous?’
