[23:96] And certainly We have the power to show thee that with which We threaten them.
[23:97] Repel evil with that which is best. We are well acquainted with <i>the things</i> they allege.
[23:98] And say, ‘My Lord, I seek refuge in Thee from the incitements of the evil ones. Footnote: And say, ‘My Lord, I seek refuge in <b>You</b> from the incitements <b>of the satans.</b>
[23:99] ‘And I seek refuge in Thee, my Lord, lest they come near me.’
[23:100] Until, when death comes to one of them, he says <i>entreating</i>, ‘My Lord, send me back,
[23:101] ‘That I may do righteous <i>deeds</i> in <i>the life</i> that I have left <i>behind.</i>’ Never, it is but a word that he utters. And behind them is a barrier until the day when they shall be raised again.
[23:102] And when the trumpet is blown, there will be no ties of relationship between them that day, nor will they ask after one another.
[23:103] Then those whose good works are heavy — these will be prosperous; Footnote: Then those whose <b>scales are heavy <i>in deeds</i>, it is there who will be prosperous.</b>
[23:104] But those whose good works are light — these are they who ruin their souls; in Hell will they abide.
[23:105] The Fire will burn their faces and they will grin <i>with fear</i> therein. Footnote: The Fire will burn their faces and they will grin therein <b><i>in agony.</i></b>
[23:106] ‘Were not My Signs recited unto you, and you treated them as lies?’
[23:107] They will say, ‘Our Lord, our wickedness overcame us, and we were an erring people.
[23:108] ‘Our Lord, take us out of this, then if we return <i>to disobedience</i>, we shall indeed be wrongdoers.
[23:109] <i>God</i> will say, “Away with you, despised therein, and speak not unto Me. Footnote: <i>God</i> will say, <b>‘Be lost therein and speak not to Me.’</b>
[23:110] “There was a party from among My servants who said, ‘Our Lord, we believe; forgive us therefore <i>our sins</i>, and have mercy on us; for Thou art the Best of those who show mercy.’
[23:111] “But you made them a laughingstock until they became the cause of your forgetting My remembrance while you <i>continued</i> laughing at them.
[23:112] “I have rewarded them this day for their steadfastness so that they alone have triumphed.”
[23:113] <i>God</i> will say, ‘What number of years did you tarry in the earth?’
[23:114] They will say, ‘We tarried for a day or part of a day, but ask those who keep count.’
[23:115] He will say, ‘You tarried but a little, if only you knew!
[23:116] ‘Did you then think that We had created you without purpose, and that you would not be brought back to Us?’
[23:117] Exalted then be Allah, the True King. There is no God but He, the Lord of the Glorious Throne. Footnote: Exalted then be Allah, <b>the Rightful Sovereign.</b>
[23:118] And he who calls on another God along with Allah, for which he has no proof, shall have to render an account to his Lord. Certainly the disbelievers will not prosper.
[23:119] And say, ‘My Lord, forgive and have mercy, and Thou art the Best of those who show mercy.’
[24:1] In the name of Allah, the Gracious, the Merciful.
[24:2] <i>This is</i> a Surah which We have revealed and which We have made obligatory; and We have revealed therein clear Signs, that you may take heed.
[24:3] The adulteress and the adulterer (or the fornicatress and the fornicator) — flog each one of them with a hundred stripes. And let not pity for the twain take hold of you in <i>executing</i> the judgment of Allah, if you believe in Allah and the Last Day. And let a party of the believers witness their punishment. Footnote: And let not pity for the twain take hold of you <b>regarding the <i>execution of the</i> divine law,</b> if you believe in Allah and the Last Day.
[24:4] The adulterer (or fornicator) shall not marry but an adulteress (or fornicatress) or an idolatrous woman, and an adulteress (or fornicatress) shall not marry but an adulterer (or fornicator) or an idolatrous man. That indeed is forbidden to the believers.
[24:5] And those who calumniate chaste women but bring not four witnesses — flog them with eighty stripes, and never admit their evidence <i>thereafter</i>, and it is they that are the transgressors,
[24:6] Except those who repent thereafter and make amends, for truly Allah is Most Forgiving, Merciful.
[24:7] And as for those who calumniate their wives, and have not witnesses except themselves — the evidence of any one of such people <i>shall suffice</i> if he bears witness four times in the name of Allah <i>saying</i> that he is surely of those who speak the truth.
[24:8] And <i>his</i> fifth <i>oath shall be to say</i> that Allah’s curse be upon him if he be of the liars.
[24:9] But it shall avert the punishment from her if she bears witness four times in the name of Allah <i>saying</i> that he is of the liars.
[24:10] And <i>her</i> fifth <i>oath shall be to say</i> that the wrath of Allah be upon her if he speaks the truth.
[24:11] And were it not for Allah’s grace and His mercy upon you, and <i>the fact</i> that Allah is Compassionate <i>and</i> Wise, <i>you would have come to grief.</i>
[24:12] Verily, those who brought forth the lie are a party from among you. Think it not to be an evil for you; nay, it is good for you. Every one of them shall have <i>his share of</i> what he has earned of the sin; and he among them who took the chief part therein shall have a grievous punishment.
[24:13] Why did not the believing men and believing women, when you heard of it, think well of their own people, and say, ‘This is a manifest lie?’
[24:14] Why did they not bring four witnesses to <i>prove</i> it? Since they have not brought the <i>required</i> witnesses, they are indeed liars in the sight of Allah!
[24:15] Were it not for the grace of Allah and His mercy upon you, in this world and the Hereafter, a great punishment would have befallen you for <i>the slander</i> into which you plunged.
[24:16] When you received it <i>and then talked about it</i> with your tongues, and you uttered with your mouths that of which you had no knowledge, and you thought it to be a light matter, while in the sight of Allah it was <i>a</i> grievous <i>thing</i>. Footnote: <b>When you pick up the word spread by your tongues and start uttering with your mouths <i>that</i> of which you have no real knowledge and consider it to be of no significance, whereas in the sight of Allah it is an enormity.</b>
[24:17] And wherefore did you not say, when you heard of it, ‘It is not proper for us to talk about it. Holy art Thou, <i>O God</i>, this is a grievous calumny!’
[24:18] Allah admonishes you never to return to the like thereof, if you are believers.
[24:19] And Allah explains to you the commandments; and Allah is All- Knowing, Wise.
[24:20] Those who love that immorality should spread among the believers, will have a painful punishment in this world and the Hereafter. And Allah knows, and you know not.
[24:21] And but for the grace of Allah and His mercy upon you and <i>the fact</i> that Allah is Compassionate <i>and</i> Merciful, <i>you would have been ruined</i>.
[24:22] O ye who believe! follow not the footsteps of Satan, and whoso follows the footsteps of Satan <i>should know that</i> he surely enjoins immorality and manifest evil. And but for the grace of Allah and His mercy upon you, not one of you would ever be pure, but Allah purifies whom He pleases. And Allah is All-Hearing, All-Knowing.
[24:23] And let not those who possess wealth and plenty among you swear not to give <i>aught</i> to the kindred and to the needy and to those who have left their homes in the cause of Allah. Let them forgive and pass over <i>the offence</i>. Do you not desire that Allah should forgive you? And Allah is Most Forgiving, Merciful. Footnote: Let them forgive and <b>forbear</b>.
[24:24] Verily, those who accuse chaste, unwary, believing women are cursed in this world and the Hereafter. And for them is a grievous chastisement,
[24:25] On the day when their tongues and their hands and their feet will bear witness against them as to what they used to do.
[24:26] On that day will Allah pay them their just due, and they will know that Allah alone is the Manifest Truth.
[24:27] Bad things are for bad men, and bad men are for bad things. And good things are for good men, and good men are for good things; these are innocent of all that they (calumniators) allege. For them is forgiveness and an honourable provision.
[24:28] O ye who believe! enter not houses other than your own until you have asked leave and saluted the inmates thereof. That is better for you, that you may be heedful.
[24:29] And if you find no one therein, do not enter them until you are given permission. And if it be said to you, ‘Go back’ then go back; that is purer for you. And Allah knows well what you do.
[24:30] It is no sin on your part to enter uninhabited houses wherein are your goods. And Allah knows what you reveal and what you conceal.
[24:31] Say to the believing men that they restrain their eyes and guard their private parts. That is purer for them. Surely, Allah is well aware of what they do.
[24:32] And say to the believing women that they restrain their eyes and guard their private parts, and that they disclose not their <i>natural and artificial</i> beauty except that which is apparent thereof, and that they draw their head-coverings over their bosoms, and that they disclose not their beauty save to their husbands, or to their fathers, or the fathers of their husbands or their sons or the sons of their husbands or their brothers, or the sons of their brothers, or the sons of their sisters, or their women, or what their right hands possess, or such of male attendants as have no sexual appetite, or young children who have no knowledge of the hidden parts of women. And they strike not their feet so that what they hide of their ornaments may become known. And turn ye to Allah all together, O believers, that you may succeed. Footnote: And say to the believing women that they restrain their eyes and guard their private parts, <b>and that they display not their beauty and embellishments except that which is apparent thereof,</b> and that they draw their head-covers over their bosoms, <b>and that they display not their beauty and embellishments thereof</b> save to their husbands, or to their fathers, or the fathers of their husbands, or their sons of the sons of their husbands, or their brothers, or the sons of their brothers, or the sons of their sisters, or their women, or what their right hands possess, or such of male attendants <b>who have no wickedness in them,</b> or young children <>who have not yet attained any concept of the private parts of women. And they walk not in a style that such of their beauty as they conceal is noticed.</b> And turn <b>you</b> to Allah altogether, O believers, that you may succeed.
[24:33] And marry widows from among you, and your male slaves and female slaves who are fit <i>for marriage</i>. If they be poor, Allah will grant them means out of His bounty; and Allah is Bountiful, All-knowing.
[24:34] And those who find no <i>means of</i> marriage should keep themselves chaste, until Allah grants them means out of His bounty. And such as desire <i>a deed of manumission in</i> writing from among those whom your right hands possess, write it for them if you know any good in them; and give them out of the wealth of Allah which He has bestowed upon you. And force not your maids to unchaste life <i>by keeping them unmarried</i> if they desire to keep chaste, in order that you may seek the gain of the present life. But if any one forces them, then after their compulsion Allah will be Forgiving <i>and</i> Merciful <i>to them</i>. Footnote: <b>And those of your slaves who desire a deed of liberation to be contracted, write it down for them if you see in them any good <i>potential and</i> give them out of that wealth which <i>truly</i> belongs to Allah which He has bestowed upon you.</b>
[24:35] And We sent down to you manifest Signs, and the example of those who have passed away before you, and an exhortation to the God-fearing.
[24:36] Allah is the Light of the heavens and the earth. The similitude of His light is as a <i>lustrous</i> niche, wherein is a lamp. The lamp is in a glass. The glass is as it were a glittering star. It is lit from a blessed tree — an olive — neither of the east nor of the west, whose oil would well-nigh glow forth even though fire touched it not. Light upon light! Allah guides to His light whomsoever He will. And Allah sets forth parables to men, and Allah knows all things full well.
[24:37] <i>This light is now lit</i> in houses with regard to which Allah has ordained that they be exalted and that His name be remembered in them. Therein is He glorified in the mornings and the evenings. Footnote: <b>Glorify Him therein in the morning and the evenings;</b>
[24:38] <i>By</i> men, whom neither merchandise nor traffic diverts from the remembrance of Allah and the observance of Prayer, and the giving of the Zakat. They fear a day in which hearts and eyes will be agitated, Footnote: <b>Men whom neither trade nor commerce makes oblivious of the remembrance of Allah</b> and the observance of Prayer, and the giving of Zakat.
[24:39] So that Allah may give them the best reward of their deeds, and give them increase out of His bounty. And Allah does provide for whomsoever He pleases without measure.
[24:40] And <i>as to</i> those who disbelieve, their deeds are like a mirage in a desert. The thirsty one thinks it to be water until, when he comes up to it, he finds it to be nothing. And he finds Allah near him, Who then fully pays him his account; and Allah is swift at reckoning. Footnote: And <i>as to</i> those who disbelieve, their deeds are like a mirage in the desert. <b>One who is thirsty considers it to be water</b> until when he comes up to it, he finds it to be nothing. <b>And he finds Allah to be there Who pays him his account;</b> And Allah is swift at reckoning.
[24:41] Or <i>their deeds are</i> like thick darkness in a vast and deep sea, which a wave covers, over which there is another wave, above which are clouds: layers of darkness, one upon another. When he holds out his hand, he can hardly see it: and he whom Allah gives no light — for him there is no light at all.
[24:42] Hast thou not seen that it is Allah Whose praises all who are in the heavens and the earth celebrate, and <i>so do</i> the birds with their wings outspread? Each one knows his own <i>mode of</i> prayer and praise. And Allah knows well what they do.
[24:43] And to Allah belongs the kingdom of the heavens and the earth, and to Allah shall be the return.
[24:44] Hast thou not seen that Allah drives the clouds, then joins them together, then piles them up so that thou seest rain issue forth from the midst thereof? And He sends down from the sky <i>clouds like</i> mountains wherein is hail, and He smites therewith whom He pleases, and turns it away from whom He pleases. The flash of its lightning may well-nigh take away the sight.
[24:45] Allah alternates the night and the day. Therein surely is a lesson for those who have eyes.
[24:46] And Allah has created every animal from water. Of them are <i>some</i> that go upon their bellies, and of them are <i>some</i> that go upon two feet, and among them are <i>some</i> that go upon four. Allah creates what He pleases. Surely, Allah has the power to do all that He pleases. Footnote: And Allah has created every animal from water. Of them are <i>some</i> that <b>crawl</b> upon their bellies, and of them are <i>some</i> that go upon two feet, and among them are <i>some</i> that go upon four.
[24:47] We have indeed sent down manifest Signs. And Allah guides whom He pleases to the right path.
[24:48] And they say, ‘We believe in Allah and in the Messenger and we obey;’ then after that some of them turn away. But such are not believers.
[24:49] And when they are called to Allah and His Messenger that he may judge between them, lo! a party of them turn away.
[24:50] And if <i>they consider</i> the right <i>to be</i> on their side, they come to him running in <i>all</i> submission.
[24:51] Is it that there is a disease in their hearts? Or do they doubt, or do they fear that Allah and His Messenger will be unjust to them? Nay, it is they themselves who are the wrongdoers.
[24:52] The response of the believers, when they are called to Allah and His Messenger in order that he may judge between them, is only that they say: ‘We hear and we obey.’ And it is they who will prosper.
[24:53] And whoso obeys Allah and His Messenger, and fears Allah, and takes Him as a shield <i>for protection</i>, it is they who will be successful.
[24:54] And they swear by Allah their strongest oaths that, if thou command them, they will surely go forth. Say, ‘Swear not; <i>what is required is actual</i> obedience in what is right. Surely, Allah is well aware of what you do.’
[24:55] Say, ‘Obey Allah, and obey the Messenger.’ But if you turn away, then upon him is his burden, and upon you is your burden. And if you obey him, you will be rightly guided. And the messenger is not responsible but for the plain delivery of the Message. Footnote: Say, ‘Obey Allah, and obey the Messenger.’ <b>And if they turn away then <i>remember, whoever does so</i> will be held responsible for that reposed in him, as also you will be held responsible for that which is reposed in you.</b>
[24:56] Allah has promised to those among you who believe and do good works that He will surely make them Successors in the earth, as He made Successors <i>from among</i> those who were before them; and that He will surely establish for them their religion which He has chosen for them; and that He will surely give them in exchange security <i>and peace</i> after their fear: They will worship Me, <i>and</i> they will not associate anything with Me. Then whoso is ungrateful after that, they will be the rebellious.
[24:57] And observe Prayer and give the Zakat and obey the Messenger, that you may be shown mercy.
[24:58] Think not that those who disbelieve can frustrate <i>Our plan</i> in the earth; their abode is Hell; and it is indeed an evil resort.
[24:59] O ye who believe! let those whom your right hands possess, and those of you who have not attained to puberty, ask leave of you at three times <i>before coming into your presence</i>: before the morning Prayer, and when you take off your clothes at noon in summer, and after the night Prayer. <i>These are</i> three times of privacy for you. At <i>times</i> other than these there is no blame on you or on them, <i>for</i> they have to move about <i>waiting upon</i> you, some of you <i>attending</i> upon others. Thus does Allah make plain to you the Signs; for Allah is All-Knowing, Wise.
[24:60] And when the children among you attain to puberty, they <i>too</i> should ask permission, even as those <i>mentioned</i> before them asked permission. Thus does Allah make plain to you His commandments; and Allah is All-Knowing, Wise.
[24:61] <i>As to</i> elderly women, who have no desire for marriage — there is no blame on them if they lay aside their <i>outer</i> clothing without displaying their beauty. But to abstain <i>from that even</i> is better for them. And Allah is All-Hearing, All-Knowing. Footnote: <i>As to</i> elderly women, who <b>are past marriageable able,</b> there is no blame on them if they lay aside their <i>outer</i> <b>garments but do not deliberately display their charms. And if they prefer to exercise more caution <i>to guard their purity</i> it is</b> <i>even</i> better for them.
[24:62] There is no harm for the blind and there is no harm for the lame, and there is no harm for the sick and none for yourselves, that you eat from your own houses, or the houses of your fathers, or the houses of your mothers or the houses of your brothers, or the houses of your sisters, or the houses of your fathers’ brothers or the houses of your fathers’ sisters, or the houses of your mothers’ brothers, or the houses of your mothers’ sisters, or <i>from</i> that of which the keys are in your possession, or <i>from the house of</i> a friend of yours. There is no harm for you whether you eat together or separately. But when you enter houses, salute your people — a greeting from your Lord, full of blessing and purity. Thus does Allah make plain to you the commandments, that you may understand.
[24:63] Those only are <i>true</i> believers who believe in Allah and His Messenger, and who, when they are with him on some matter <i>of common importance</i> which has brought <i>them</i> together, go not away until they have asked leave of him. Surely those who ask leave of thee, it is they who <i>really</i> believe in Allah and His Messenger. So, when they ask thy leave for some affair of theirs, give leave to those of them whom thou pleasest, and ask forgiveness for them of Allah. Surely, Allah is Most Forgiving, Merciful. Footnote: <b>Verily, the true believers are only those</b> who believe in Allah and His Messenger <b>and do not leave without seeking permission from him</b> when they are with him on some matter of <b>collective importance.</b> Surely, those who ask leave of <b>you,</b> it is they who <i>really</i> believe in Allah and His Messenger. So, when they ask <b>your</b> leave for some affair of theirs, give leave to those of them whom <b>you please,</b> and ask forgiveness of <b>Allah for them.</b>
[24:64] Treat not the calling of the Messenger among you like the calling of one of you to another. Allah does know those of you who steal away covertly. So let those who go against His command beware lest a trial afflict them or a grievous punishment overtake them.
[24:65] Hearken ye! To Allah belongs whatsoever is in the heavens and the earth. He does know in what condition you are. To Allah belongs whatsoever is in the heavens and the earth. <b>Verily, He knows what you are.</b> And on the day when they will be returned <b>to</b> Him, He will inform them of what they did.
[25:1] In the name of Allah, the Gracious, the Merciful.
[25:2] Blessed is He Who has sent down the Discrimination to His servant, that he may be a Warner to <i>all</i> the worlds — 
[25:3] He to Whom belongs the kingdom of the heavens and the earth. And He has taken unto Himself no son, and has no partner in the kingdom, and has created everything, and has ordained for it <i>its</i> proper measure.
[25:4] Yet they have taken beside Him gods, who create nothing but are themselves created, and who have no power to harm or benefit themselves and they control not death nor life nor resurrection.
[25:5] And those who disbelieve say, ‘It is naught but a lie which he has forged, and other people have helped him with it.’ Indeed, they have brought forth an injustice and an untruth.
[25:6] And they say, ‘<i>These are</i> fables of the ancients; <i>and</i> he has got them written down, and they are dictated to him morning and evening.’
[25:7] Say, ‘He Who knows <i>every</i> secret <i>that is</i> in the heavens and the earth has revealed it. Verily, He is Most Forgiving, Merciful.’
[25:8] And they say, ‘What is the matter with this Messenger that he eats food, and walks in the streets? Why has not an angel been sent down to him that he might be a warner with him?
[25:9] ‘Or a treasure should have been thrown down to him, or he should have had a garden to eat therefrom.’ And the wrongdoers say, ‘You follow none but a man bewitched.’
[25:10] See how they coin similitudes for thee! Thus they have gone astray and cannot find a way.
[25:11] Blessed is He Who, if He please, will assign thee better than all that — Gardens through which rivers flow — and will <i>also</i> assign thee palaces.
[25:12] Nay, they deny the Hour, and for those who deny the Hour We have prepared a blazing fire.
[25:13] When it sees them from a place far off, they will hear its raging and roaring.
[25:14] And when they are thrown into a narrow place thereof, chained together, they will pray there for destruction.
[25:15] ‘Pray not today for one destruction, but pray for many destructions.’
[25:16] Say, ‘Is that better or the Garden of Eternity, which is promised to the righteous? It will be their reward and resort.’
[25:17] They will have therein whatsoever they desire, abiding <i>therein for ever</i>. It is a promise from thy Lord, to be <i>always</i> prayed for.
[25:18] And the day when He will assemble them and those whom they worship beside Allah, He will ask, ‘Was it you who led astray these My servants, or did they <i>themselves</i> stray away from the path?’
[25:19] They will say, ‘Holy art Thou! It was not proper for us to take protectors other than Thee; but Thou didst bestow on them and their fathers the good things <i>of this life</i> until they forgot the admonition and became a ruined people.’
[25:20] <i>Then We shall say to the idolaters</i>: ‘Now have they given you the lie regarding what you said, so you cannot avert <i>the punishment</i> or <i>get</i> help.’ And whosoever among you does wrong, We shall make him taste a grievous punishment.
[25:21] And We never sent any Messengers before thee but surely they ate food and walked in the streets. And We make some of you a trial for others. Will you <i>then</i> be steadfast? And thy Lord is All- Seeing.
[25:22] And those who look not for a meeting with Us say: ‘Why are angels not sent down to us? Or why do we not see our Lord?’ Surely they are too proud of themselves and have greatly exceeded the bounds.
[25:23] On the day when they see the angels — there will be no good tidings on that day for the guilty; and they will say: ‘Would that there were a great barrier!’
[25:24] And We shall turn to the works they did and We shall scatter it into particles of dust. Footnote: And <b>We will turn to each of their deeds that they performed and render it into scattered particles of dust.</b>
[25:25] The inmates of Heaven on that day will be better off as regards <i>their</i> abode, and better off in respect of <i>their</i> place of repose.
[25:26] And the day when the heaven shall be rent asunder with the clouds, and the angels shall be sent down in large numbers — 
[25:27] The true kingdom shall that day belong to the Gracious <i>God</i>; and it shall be a hard day for the disbelievers.
[25:28] <i>Remember</i> the day when the wrongdoer will bite his hands; he will say, ‘O, would that I had taken <i>the same</i> way with the Messenger! Footnote: <b><i>Beware of</i></b> the day when the wrongdoers will <b>gnaw at</b> his hands <b><i>in utter helplessness;</i></b> he will say, <b>‘Would, that I had trodden</b> <i>the same</i> <b>path along</b> with the Messenger.’
[25:29] ‘Ah, woe is me! Would that I had never taken such a one for a friend!
[25:30] ‘He led me astray from the Reminder after it had come to me.’ And Satan is man’s great deserter.
[25:31] And the Messenger will say, ‘O my Lord, my people indeed treated this Qur’an as <i>a</i> discarded <i>thing</i>.’
[25:32] Thus did We make for every Prophet an enemy from among the sinners; and sufficient is thy Lord as a Guide and a Helper.
[25:33] And those who disbelieve say, ‘Why was not the Qur’an revealed to him all at once?’ <i>We have revealed it</i> thus that We may strengthen thy heart therewith. And We have arranged it in the best form.
[25:34] And they bring thee no similitude but We provide thee with the truth and an excellent explanation.
[25:35] Those who will be gathered on their faces unto Hell — they will be the worst in plight and most astray from the <i>right</i> path.
[25:36] We gave Moses the Book, and appointed with him his brother Aaron as <i>his</i> assistant.
[25:37] And We said, ‘Go both of you to the people who have rejected Our Signs;’ then We destroyed them, an utter destruction.
[25:38] And <i>as to</i> the people of Noah when they rejected the Messengers, We drowned them, and We made them a Sign for mankind. And We have prepared a painful punishment for the wrongdoers.
[25:39] And <i>We destroyed</i> ‘Ad and Thamud, and the People of the Well, and many a generation between them.
[25:40] And to each one We set forth <i>clear</i> similitudes; and each one We completely destroyed. Footnote: <b>And to each of them We related the examples <i>of earlier people;</i> and one and all We utterly destroyed.</b>
[25:41] And these (Meccans) must have visited the town whereon was rained an evil rain. Have they not then seen it? Nay, they hope not to be raised <i>after death</i>. Footnote: And these must have visited the town <b>on which</b> was rained an evil rain.
[25:42] And when they see thee, they only make a jest of thee: ‘Is this he whom Allah has sent <i>as</i> a Messenger?
[25:43] ‘He indeed had well-nigh led us astray from our gods, had we not steadily adhered to them.’ And they shall know, when they see the punishment, who is most astray from the <i>right</i> path.
[25:44] Hast thou seen him who takes his own evil desire for his god? Couldst thou then be a guardian over him?
[25:45] Dost thou think that most of them hear or understand? They are only like cattle — nay, they are worst astray from the path.
[25:46] Hast thou not seen how thy Lord lengthens the shade? And if He had pleased, He could have made it stationary. Then We make the sun a guide thereof.
[25:47] Then We draw it in towards Ourself, an easy drawing in.
[25:48] And He it is Who has made the night a covering for you, and <i>Who has made</i> sleep for rest, and has made the day for rising up.
[25:49] And He it is Who sends the winds as glad tidings before His mercy, and We send down pure water from the sky,
[25:50] That We may thereby give life to a dead land, and give it for drink to Our creation — cattle and men in great numbers.
[25:51] And We have explained it to them in diverse ways that they may take heed, but most men would reject everything but disbelief.
[25:52] If We had pleased, We could have surely raised a Warner in every city.

[25:54] And He it is Who has caused the two seas to flow, this palatable <i>and</i> sweet, and that saltish <i>and</i> bitter; and between them He has placed a barrier and a great partition.

[25:59] And trust thou in the Living One, Who dies not, and glorify <i>Him</i> with His praise. And sufficient is He as the Knower of the sins of His servants,

[25:63] And He it is Who has made the night and the day, each following the other, for him who desires to remember, or desires to be grateful.
[25:64] And the servants of the Gracious <i>God</i> are those who walk on the earth in a dignified manner, and when the ignorant address them, they say, ‘Peace!’
[25:65] And who spend the night before their Lord, prostrate and standing,
[25:66] And who say, ‘Our Lord, avert from us the punishment of Hell; for the punishment thereof is a lasting torment.
[25:67] ‘It is indeed evil as a place of rest and as an abode;’
[25:68] And those who, when they spend, are neither extravagant nor niggardly but moderate between the two;

[25:70] Doubled to him will be the punishment on the Day of Resurrection, and he will abide therein disgraced,

[25:72] And those who repent and do good <i>deeds</i>, indeed turn to Allah with <i>true</i> repentance;
[25:73] And those who bear not false witness, and when they pass by anything vain, they pass on with dignity;

[27:2] Ta Sin. These are verses of the Qur’an, and of an illuminating Book, Footnote: Benignant, All-Hearing God!
[27:3] A guidance and good tidings to those who would believe,
[27:4] Who observe Prayer and pay the Zakat, and have firm faith in the Hereafter.
[27:5] <i>As to</i> those who believe not in the Hereafter, We have made their deeds <i>appear</i> beautiful to them, so they are wandering blindly.
[27:6] It is they who shall have a grievous torment, and they alone it is who shall be the greatest losers in the Hereafter.
[27:7] Verily, thou hast been given the Qur’an from the presence of One Wise, All-Knowing.
[27:8] <i>Remember</i> when Moses said to his family, ‘I perceive a fire. I will bring you from there some information, or I will bring you a flame, a <i>burning</i> brand, that you may warm yourselves.’
[27:9] So when he came to it, he was called <i>by a voice</i>: ‘Blessed is he who is in the fire and <i>also</i> those around it; and glorified be Allah, the Lord of the worlds.
[27:10] ‘O Moses verily I am Allah, the Mighty, the Wise.
[27:11] ‘And throw down thy rod.’ And when he saw it move as though it were a serpent, he turned back retreating and did not look back. ‘O Moses, fear not. Verily I am <i>with</i> <i>thee</i>; the Messengers need have no fear in My presence.
[27:12] ‘As to those who do wrong and then substitute good for evil; <i>to them</i>, I am indeed Most Forgiving, Merciful.
[27:13] ‘And put thy hand into thy bosom; it will come forth white without any disease. <i>This is</i> among the nine Signs unto Pharaoh and his people; for they are a rebellious people.’ Footnote: ‘And <b>insert your hand into your bosom <i>under your garment,</i></b> it will come forth white, <b>without blemish.</b>
[27:14] But when Our sight giving Signs came to them, they said, ‘This is plain magic.’
[27:15] And they rejected them wrongfully and arrogantly, while their souls were convinced of them. See then, how <i>evil</i> was the end of those who acted corruptly!
[27:16] And We gave knowledge to David and Solomon, and they said, ‘All praise belongs to Allah, Who has exalted us above many of His believing servants.’
[27:17] And Solomon was heir to David. And he said, ‘O ye people, we have been taught the language of birds; and we have had everything bestowed upon us. This indeed is <i>God</i>’<i>s</i> manifest grace.’
[27:18] And there were gathered together unto Solomon his hosts of Jinn and men and birds, and they were formed into <i>separate</i> divisions,
[27:19] Until when they came to the Valley of Al-Naml, one woman <i>of the tribe</i> of the Naml said, ‘O ye Naml, enter your habitations, lest Solomon and his hosts crush you, while they know not.’ Footnote: Until when they came to the Valley of Al-Naml, <b>a Namlite woman said,</b> ‘O ye Naml, enter your habitations, lest Solomon and his hosts crush you, while they know not.’
[27:20] Thereupon he smiled, laughing at her words, and said, ‘My Lord, grant me <i>the will and power</i> to be grateful for Thy favour which Thou hast bestowed upon me and upon my parents, and to do <i>such</i> good works as would please Thee, and admit me, by Thy mercy, among Thy righteous servants.’ Footnote: Thereupon he smiled, laughing at her words, and said, ‘My Lord, <b>enable me to be grateful</b> for <b>Your</b> favour which <b>You have</b> bestowed upon me and upon my parents, and to do <i>such</i> good works as would please <b>You</b>, and admit me, by <b>Your</b> mercy, among <b>Your</b> righteous servants.’
[27:21] And he reviewed the birds, and said, ‘How is it that I do not see Hudhud? Is he among the absentees? Footnote: And he <b>examined</b> the birds, and said, ‘How is it that I do not see Hudhud?’
[27:22] ‘I will surely punish him with a severe punishment or I will slay him, unless he bring me a clear reason <i>for his absence</i>.’ Footnote: ‘I will <b>subject him to</b> severe punishment or I will slay him, unless he brings me a clear reason <i>for his absence.’</i>
[27:23] And he did not tarry long <i>before Hudhud came</i> and said, ‘I have encompassed that which thou hast not encompassed; and I have come to thee from Saba’ with sure tidings.
[27:24] ‘I found a woman ruling over them, and she has been given everything, and she has a mighty throne.
[27:25] ‘I found her and her people worshipping the sun instead of Allah; and Satan has made their works <i>look</i> beautiful to them, and has thus hindered them from the <i>right</i> way, so that they follow not guidance;
[27:26] ‘<i>And Satan has bidden them</i> not to worship Allah, Who brings to light that which is hidden in the heavens and the earth, and Who knows what you conceal and what you make known.
[27:27] ‘Allah! there is no God but He, the Lord of the Mighty Throne.’
[27:28] <i>Solomon</i> said, ‘We shall see whether thou hast spoken the truth or whether thou art one of those who lie.
[27:29] ‘Go thou, with this letter of mine, and lay it before them; then withdraw from them and see what <i>answer</i> they return.’
[27:30] <i>The Queen</i> said, “Ye chiefs, there has been delivered to me a noble letter.
[27:31] “It is from Solomon, and it is: ‘In the name of Allah, the Gracious, the Merciful;
[27:32] ‘Behave not proudly towards me, but come to me in submission.’”
[27:33] She said, ‘Ye chiefs, advise me in the matter that is before me. I never decide any matter until you are present with me <i>and give me your advice</i>.’
[27:34] They replied, ‘We possess power and we possess great prowess in war, but it is for thee to command; therefore consider thou what thou wilt command.’ Footnote: They replied, ‘We possess power and <b>we are fierce fighters,</b> but it is for <b>you</b> to command; therefore consider <b>you</b> what <b>you will</b> command.’
[27:35] She said, ‘Surely, kings, when they enter a country, despoil it, and turn the highest of its people into the lowest. And thus will they do.
[27:36] ‘But I am going to send them a present and wait to see what <i>answer</i> the envoys bring back.’
[27:37] So when <i>the Queen</i>’<i>s ambassador</i> came to Solomon, he said, ‘Do you mean to help me with <i>your</i> wealth? But that which Allah has given me is better than that which He has given you. Nay, but you rejoice in your gift.
[27:38] ‘Go back to them, for we shall surely come to them with hosts against which they will have no power, and we shall drive them out from there disgraced, and they will be humbled.’
[27:39] He said, ‘O nobles, which of you will bring me a throne for her before they come to me, submitting?’ Footnote: He said, ‘O nobles, which of you will bring me <b>her throne</b> before they come to me <b>offering submission</b>?’ <b>Note:</b> From the following verses, it becomes clear that Solomon does not refer to her throne itself. He either means a throne very similar to hers should be manufactured or that a very faithful replica of her throne should be brought to him. Before her intended visit to the court of Solomon, she is given the surprise of finding the throne very similar to her own but in the possession of Solomon. From the verses which follow, the scenario that emerges clearly indicates that each of the nobles of his court wanted the task to be assigned to him, each boasting to perform the task quicker and better than his rivals. Ultimately, when the replica was first presented to him, he praised God for it and issued instructions to modify it further so that it might resemble the Queen of Saba’s throne ever more closely and so deflate her pride in possessing a unique throne. The expression <i>nakkiru laha ‘arshaha</i> (<b></b>) clearly supports this meaning and implies that if she saw a throne very similar to her own, she would naturally infer that her own throne was not as unique and special as she thought it was. So the meaning of <i>nakkiru</i> (<b></b>) in this context would make her throne seem common-looking. When she actually saw the throne built by Solomon’s craftsmen, her response was not that of a Queen who only recently had her own throne stolen, nor that of a Queen who could not recognize her own throne because the craftsmen had worked on it to render it unrecognizable. Her response is simply that of a person who finds an article similar to her own. This clearly proves that the scenario we have visualized is more realistic.
[27:40] Said a stalwart from among the Jinn: ‘I will bring it to thee before thou rise from thy camp; and indeed I possess power therefore <i>and I am</i> trustworthy.’
[27:41] Said one who had knowledge of the Book, ‘I will bring it to thee before thy noble <i>messengers</i> return to thee.’ And when he saw it set before him, he said, ‘This is by the grace of my Lord, that He may try me whether I am grateful or ungrateful. And whosoever is grateful is grateful for the good of his <i>own</i> soul; but whosoever is ungrateful, truly my Lord is Self- Sufficient, Generous.’ Footnote: Said one who had knowledge of the Book, ‘I will bring it to <b>you quicker than the blinking of your eye.</b>
[27:42] He said, ‘Make her throne unrecognizable to her, and let us see whether she follows the right way or whether she is <i>one</i> of those who follow not the right way.’ Footnote: Make her Throne <b>appear commonplace to her,</b>
[27:43] And when she came, it was said, ‘Is thy throne like this?’ She replied, ‘It is as though it were the same. And we had been given knowledge before this, and we have already submitted.’
[27:44] And that which she used to worship beside Allah had stopped her <i>from believing</i>; for she came of a disbelieving people.
[27:45] It was said to her, ‘Enter the palace.’ And when she saw it, she thought it to be a great expanse of water, and she uncovered her shanks. <i>Solomon</i> said, ‘It is a palace paved smooth with slabs of glass.’ She said, ‘My Lord, I indeed wronged my soul; and I submit myself with Solomon to Allah, the Lord of the worlds.’ Footnote: <b>Note:</b> Clear, high-quality glass, deftly laid, can create the impression of water and that is what actually happened. The message delivered to the Queen, who was exceptionally intelligent, was that sometimes things are very different from the impressions they create, and the qualities they reflect, do not belong to them. Similarly, the impression of glory and power created by the sun, does not belong to it but belongs only to the Creator.
[27:46] And We sent to Thamud their brother Salih, <i>who said</i>, ‘Worship Allah.’ But behold, they became two parties contending with each other.
[27:47] He said, ‘O my people, why do you wish to hasten on the evil rather than the good? Wherefore do you not ask forgiveness of Allah that you may be shown mercy?’
[27:48] They said, ‘We auger evil from thee and from those that are with thee.’ He said, ‘<i>The cause of</i> your evil fortune is with Allah. Nay, but you are a people who are on trial.’ Footnote: They said, ‘We augur <b>ill of you and of those</b> that are with <b>you.’</b>
[27:49] And there were in the city a party of nine <i>persons</i> who made mischief in the land, and would not reform.
[27:50] They said, “Swear to each other by Allah that we will surely attack him and his family by night, and then we will say to his heir, ‘We witnessed not the destruction of his family, and most surely we are truthful.’”
[27:51] And they planned a plan, and We planned a plan, but they perceived <i>it</i> not. Footnote: And they <b>wove a plot</b> and We <b>wove a <i>counter</i> plot</b> but they <b>were unaware of <i>it.</i></b>
[27:52] Then see how <i>evil</i> was the end of their plan! Verily, We utterly destroyed them and their people all together.
[27:53] And yonder are their houses empty, because of their wrongdoing. In that, verily, is a Sign for a people who possess knowledge. Footnote: And yonder <b>lie</b> their houses empty, because of their wrongdoing.
[27:54] And We saved those who believed and feared God.
[27:55] And <i>remember</i> Lot, when he said to his people, ‘Do you commit abomination while you see <i>the evil thereof</i> ?
[27:56] What! do you approach men lustfully rather than women? Nay, you are indeed an ignorant people.’ Footnote: ‘What! Do you approach men lustfully rather than women? Nay, you are indeed <b>a people unmindful of consequences.’</b>
[27:57] But the answer of his people was naught save that they said, ‘Drive out Lot’s family from your city. [28:13] And We had already ordained that he shall refuse the wet nurses; so she said, ‘Shall I tell you of a household who will bring him up for you and will be his sincere well-wishers?’ Footnote: And We had already <b>made wet nurses unacceptable to him;</b> so she said, <b>‘Shall I lead you to</b> a household who will bring him up for you and will be his sincere well-wishers?’

[28:20] And when he made up his mind to lay hold of the man who was an enemy to both of them, he said, ‘O Moses, dost thou intend to kill me as thou didst kill a man yesterday? Thou only intend est to become a tyrant in the land, and thou intendest not to be a peacemaker.’
[28:21] And there came a man from the far side of the city, running. He said, ‘O Moses, of a truth, the chiefs are taking counsel together against thee to kill thee. Therefore get thee away; surely I am of thy well-wishers.’
[28:22] So he went forth therefrom, fearing, watchful. He said, ‘My Lord, deliver me from the unjust people.’
[28:23] And when he turned his face towards Midian, he said, ‘I hope my Lord will guide me to the right way.’

[28:25] So he watered <i>their flocks</i> for them. [28:27] One of the two <i>women</i> said, ‘O my father, hire him; for the best man that thou canst hire is the one who is strong and trustworthy.’

[28:30] And when Moses had fulfilled the term, and journeyed with his family, he perceived a fire in the direction of the Mount. He said to his family, ‘Wait, I perceive a fire; haply I may bring you some <i>useful</i> information therefrom, or a burning brand from the fire that you may warm yourselves.’
[28:31] And when he came to it, he was called <i>by a voice</i> from the right side of the Valley, in the blessed spot, out of the tree: ‘O Moses, verily I am, I am Allah, the Lord of the worlds.’ Footnote: ‘O Moses, <b>surely I, <i>none but</i> I, am Allah,</b> the Lord of the worlds.’
[28:32] And <i>it also said</i>: ‘Throw down thy rod.’ And when he saw it move as though it were a serpent, he turned back retreating and did not wait. ‘ O Moses, come forward and fear not; surely thou art of those who are safe.
[28:33] ‘Insert thy hand into thy bosom; it will come forth white without evil <i>effect</i>, and draw back thy arm toward thyself <i>to be free</i> from fear. So these <i>shall be</i> two proofs from thy Lord to Pharaoh and his chiefs. Surely they are a rebellious people.’
[28:34] He said, ‘My Lord, I killed a person from among them, and I fear that they will kill me.
[28:35] ‘And my brother Aaron — he is more eloquent in speech than I; send him therefore with me as a helper that he may bear witness to my truth. I fear that they will accuse me of falsehood.’
[28:36] <i>God</i> said, ‘We will strengthen thy arm with thy brother and We will give power to you both so that they shall not be able to reach you. <i>Go</i> with Our Signs. You two and those who follow you will be the winners.’
[28:37] And when Moses came to them with Our clear Signs, they said, ‘This is nothing but sorcery devised, and we never heard <i>the like</i> of this among our forefathers.’
[28:38] Moses said, ‘My Lord knows best who it is that has brought guidance from Him, and whose will be the reward of the <i>final</i> abode. Verily, the wrongdoers never prosper.’
[28:39] And Pharaoh said, ‘O chiefs, I know of no God for you other than myself; so burn me <i>bricks of</i> clay, O Haman, and build me a tower, that I may have a look at the God of Moses, though I believe him to be one of the liars.’ Footnote: and build me a tower, that I may have a <b>glimpse</b> of the God of Moses, though I believe him to be one of the liars.’
[28:40] And he and his hosts behaved arrogantly in the land without any justification. And they thought that they would never be brought back to Us.
[28:41] So We seized him and his hosts, and cast them into the sea. See, then, how <i>evil</i> was the end of the wrongdoers!
[28:42] And We made them leaders inviting <i>people</i> unto the Fire; and on the Day of Resurrection they will receive no help.
[28:43] And We caused them to be followed by a curse in this world; and on the Day of Resurrection they will be among those deprived of <i>all</i> good.
[28:44] And We gave the Book to Moses, after We had destroyed the earlier generations, as <i>a source of</i> enlightenment for men, and a guidance and a mercy, that they might reflect.
[28:45] And thou wast not on the western side <i>of the Mount</i> when We revealed the command to Moses, nor wast thou among the witnesses.
[28:46] But We brought forth generations <i>after Moses</i>, and life became prolonged for them. And thou wast not a dweller among the people of Midian, rehearsing Our Signs unto them; but it is We Who sent Messengers.
[28:47] And thou wast not at the side of the Mount when We called. But <i>We have sent thee as</i> a mercy from thy Lord, that thou mayest warn a people to whom no Warner had come before thee, that they may reflect.
[28:48] And had it not been <i>for the fact</i> that, if an affliction should befall them because of what their hands have sent before <i>them</i>, they would say, ‘Our Lord, wherefore didst Thou not send a Messenger to us that we might have followed Thy Signs, and been of the believers?’ <i>We should not have sent thee as a Messenger</i>. Footnote: <b>And why do they not, when an affliction befalls them as a result of their own doings, say,</b> ‘Our Lord, <b>why did you not send your Messenger to us so that we could follow Your</b> Signs, <b>and be of those who believed</b>?’ <b>Note:</b> The answer to this question is implied and the reason why they cannot blame Allah, is because God always sends warners to people before punishing them for their misdeeds. See chapter 6 verse 132.
[28:49] But when the truth came to them from Us, they said, ‘Why has he not been given the like of what was given to Moses?’ Did they not reject that which was given to Moses before? They say, ‘Two <i>works</i> of sorcery — <i>the Torah and the Qur</i>’<i>an —</i> that back up each other.’ And they say, ‘We disbelieve in all.’ Footnote: But when the truth came to them from Us, they said, ‘Why has he not been given the like of what was given to Moses?’ <b>Had they not rejected what</b> was given to Moses before <b>they said, <i>Merely</i> two magicians helping each other.’</b> And they <b>said, ‘We reject them one and all.’</b> <b>Note:</b> Of the three main opponents of Islam – the Jews, Christians and the idolaters – the Jews are being addressed in this verse. This statement could only have been made by the Jews. When the Holy Qur’an says that they had rejected what was given to Moses before, it could not have meant that the people of the time of the Holy Prophet (may peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) of Islam had rejected Moses. The part of the verse comprising <i>‘inna bikullin kafirun’</i> (<b></b>) (We reject them one and all) also means that ‘we reject all those who come in the name of God with the so-called Signs.’ This pinpoints the malady shared by all those who reject the Prophet of their time.

Instead of <i>akhirah</i> (<b></b>) there the word <i>ukhra</i> (<b></b>) is used. <i>Akhirah</i> (<b></b>) can be simply translated as ‘later’ <i>ukhra</i> (<b></b>) means ‘another’. It is obvious therefore the words <i>ukhra</i> (<b></b>) and <i>akhirah</i> (<b></b>) when combined would mean: <b>another type of creation in a later age.</b>
